description: Some people are in no hurry to open their mail, but on receiving a check, most waste no time in cashing it. City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday that one city office routinely waited weeks or months to do either.

title: Looking Beyond Fields of Play
description: The reform movement in intercollegiate athletics began here 12 years ago. Yesterday, the movement got a taste of its own medicine when the Rainbow Coalition unveiled a plan to steer black recruits away from schools with poor records of minority hiring.

title: New Editor at Food & Wine
description: Dana Cowin, executive editor of Food & Wine magazine, has been promoted to editor in chief. She replaces Mary Simons, who has stepped down.

title: Photos Show Iraqis With Stolen Kuwaiti Arms
description: The United States offered the Security Council pictures today to prove that when Iraqi troops moved toward the Kuwaiti border last October they were armed with advanced equipment stolen from Kuwait during the Persian Gulf war.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about President Clinton's choice of Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut as chairman of the Democratic National Committee referred incorrectly to the history of a part-time chairmanship. Senator Dodd's double role indeed has a precedent: in July 1960, Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington was elected chairman and served part time until the inauguration of President John F. Kennedy, in January 1961.

title: Suspect Told Police He Found Firebomb in Bag
description: The paper bag was crumpled up on the floor in the subway car when he first saw it. He looked in and saw two jars containing what looked like chicken soup. Suddenly, it just "went up." And he was on fire.

title: Pope Starts Tour Today To Australia And Asia
description: Defying signs of physical weakness and ill health, Pope John Paul II plans to embark on Wednesday on his longest trip in three years, an 11-day, 20,800-mile visit to Asia and Australia that seems more than ever to raise the question: What drives him to such grueling odysseys?

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Ousts Borden Chief Executive
description: Quickly consolidating its control of Borden Inc., Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company yesterday ousted Ervin R. Shames, Borden's chief executive for little more than a year. His replacement, an aggressive marketer from the Kohlberg, Kravis roster of managers, is C. Robert Kidder, former chief executive of Duracell International Inc.

title: It's Time to Mind Your E-Manners
description: IN the pre-computer days of fountain pens and monogrammed stationery, Amy Vanderbilt and Emily Post offered advice about which fork to use and how to R.S.V.P. Now their successors are offering advice on when to throw in an emoticon, why "spamming" is a no-no and when to use abbreviations like IMHO and BTW.

title: 70 Changes Urged to Insure Airline Safety
description: A two-day emergency conference on airline safety ended today with 70 recommendations for sweeping changes in equipment and training. But many of those recommendations have been made before, and industry experts and government regulators alike agreed that one problem is that the Federal Aviation Administration has been slow to act in the past.

title: Republicans in House Begin Hearings in a Search for 'Billions' in Fiscal Fat
description: Flashing a machete, a bowie knife and a tool for skinning alligators, Representative Robert L. Livingston today formally began the Republican effort to reduce the size and cost of the Federal Government, promising major spending cuts as he presided at the opening meeting of the House Appropriations Committee.

title: Beating Horror by Becoming Wise
description: CHILDREN AND FOOLS By Erich Fried 168 pages. Serpent's Tail. $14.99

title: Malcolm X: Reopening The Files
description: "Brother Minister: The Assassination of Malcolm X" does not inspire confidence when it begins with video clips from MTV and "A Current Affair" proclaiming that this film will deliver a bombshell. The revelation in question, made public long before the film had a New York theatrical booking (it opens today at the 57th Street Playhouse in Manhattan), is neither definitive nor shocking enough to live up to its tabloid fanfare.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Sports of The Times; Those Rinks Could Have Been Filled
description: THERE should have been nine games in the National Hockey League tonight. Three in the New York area. Three in Canada, the homeland of hockey. Nine loud, colorful evenings of athletic aggression on ice.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Historian's Dismissal
description: The former House historian's supporters said Newt Gingrich was aware of her statements about an educational program on the Holocaust that he cited in dismissing her. But he denied knowing of them. Page A19.

title: INSIDE
description: 'One Never-Ending Storm'

title: High Court Restricts Admissibility of Statements by Accusers
description: Overturning a child abuse conviction, the Supreme Court today made it harder for prosecutors to bring witnesses before a jury to testify about what the ostensible victim told them about the events in question.

title: Turning In the Paintbrush for Bikes
description: Of all the new shows crowding the television schedule this month, none have more sustained energy and promise than CBS's "Double Rush." Robert Pastorelli, formerly Eldin the house painter on "Murphy Brown," stars as Johnny Verona, a lovable lug who owns a Manhattan bicycle-messenger service. Back in the 1960's, Johnny was a rock musician who dreamed of being a legend yet turned down a lucrative contract because the rest of his group wasn't included in the offer. He still has a heart of gold, along with some treasured photographs taken with Eric Clapton and Pete Townshend and a Fender Stratocaster guitar once owned by Jimi Hendrix.

title: NEW JAPAN ACCESS FOR WALL STREET
description: The United States and Japan reached a broad accord today to open a range of Japanese financial markets to foreign competition, allowing American investment firms for the first time to vie for the right to manage nearly a trillion dollars in Japanese pension funds.

title: Clinton Has Tough Plan on Refusal to Work
description: Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, told Congress today that the Administration would support separating children from their parents in some cases in which the parents repeatedly refused to work while receiving cash welfare benefits.

title: Let's Put Christmas Trees Back in the Soil
description: To the Editor:

title: Businesses Face the Facts of Curbs on Smoking
description: After months of fighting it, businesses have begun dealing with the reality of the smoking law signed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday.

title: Capital's Virtual Reality: Gingrich Rides a 3d Wave
description: All kings have their courts.

title: The Plots Thicken as Battles for No. 1 Begin
description: While Pete Sampras is looking to tighten his stranglehold on the pinnacle of men's tennis by reprising his 1994 Australian Open victory and fend off the frightening apparition of a suddenly clean-cut Andre Agassi, Steffi Graf is already sidelined by injury and incapable of defending her sole Grand Slam crown of last year, a predicament that has left her No. 1 ranking vulnerable.

title: New York Students Excel in Science Contest
description: More than a quarter of the semifinalists -- 84 of 300 -- in the prestigious Westinghouse Science Award national school competition are from New York City schools, school officials said yesterday.

title: Laidlaw Inc.(LDW.B,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included pretax equity in earnings of associated companies of $ 2 million in the latest first quarter and $ 9.7 million in year-ago period.In comparing net income year-to-year, the latest quarter included no income from ADT Ltd. and only a minimal final contribution from Attwoods plc.The contribution from these equity holdings accounted for 3.5 cents per share in the 1993 first quarter. Share earnings from ADT in year-ago first quarter equaled 2 cents a share.Laidlaw also has class A stock with the ticker symbol LDW.A.Revenue represented total revenue.

title: Battered Bunch of Nets Can't Beat Their Match
description: Ice packs, surgical tape and blank stares littered their locker room tonight. Amid the aftermath of another deflating loss, someone offered this blunt assessment:

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stock prices rose here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 47.02 points, or 0.24 percent, at 19,548.47. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 56.53 points.

title: What's So Special About Clinic Violence?
description: To the Editor:

title: First Empire State Corp.(FES,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: First Empire State said that taxable-equivalent net interest income in 1994 was $ 472.2 million, down slightly from $ 474.8 million in 1993.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Congressional debate over a balanced-budget amendment misstated the extent of its support among Democrats. While Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate minority leader, supports such an amendment, he is not alone. Others, including Senator Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, agree with him.

title: Don't Exaggerate Iranian Nuclear Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Staff Builders Inc.(SBLI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
A Lesson for Mr. Gingrich
description: Small-town cronyism is passable in small towns but dangerous when transplanted to Washington. The Clinton Administration has learned that time and again. Newt Gingrich is learning it too.

title: Personal Health
description: IN recent decades the egg, like Humpty Dumpty, has had a great fall. Since the mid-1940's, concern about cholesterol and heart disease has sent per capita consumption plummeting from more than 400 eggs a year to only 235 in 1992, according to the latest figures available.

title: BOEING GETS $600 MILLION ORDER FROM CHINESE AIRLINE
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it had received a $600 million order from China Yunnan Airlines for three 767-300 wide-body jetliners and options on three more. The order is the first for Boeing in more than a year from a Government-controlled airline in China, a Boeing spokesman said. Boeing, based in Seattle, was among the American companies that lobbied for President Clinton to renew trade ties with China last May. Boeing has said it expects China to be the fastest-growing market in the world for airline travel.

title: HOME HOLDINGS INVESTORS FORM COMMITTEE ON DEAL
description: Investors in bonds issued by Home Holdings Inc. have formed a committee and hired a New York law firm, Anderson Kill Olick & Oshinsky, to represent their interests in the insurer's proposed combination with Zurich Insurance Group. In a letter last week to directors of Home Holdings, the bondholders said a plan by Home's parent company, Trygg-Hansa A.B. of Sweden, to form an alliance with Zurich in Europe and to liquidate Home while Zurich issued new policies for selected Home customers, was not satisfactory. Some of Home's policyholders also say the agreement with Zurich leaves them less well off than if Home were to stay in business. Both groups prefer an offer from Fund American Enterprises Holdings of Norwich, Vt., to inject new capital into Home and allow it to continue in business.

title: Transit Police Chief Says He Will Retire
description: Chief Michael O'Connor of the transit police, an ardent opponent of the Giuliani administration's plan to merge New York City's three police forces, said yesterday that he would retire later this month.

title: H.M.O.'s Are Changing the Face of Medicare
description: Just as the ads had promised, it sounded too good to be true. Over muffins and coffee at the Jericho Diner in Mineola, L.I., about 25 elderly men and women listened as Paula Cardozo, a sales manager with Oxford Health Plans, described the benefits of joining her health maintenance organization for people on Medicare.

title: Kathleen Tynan, 57, a Novelist And Her Husband's Biographer
description: Kathleen Tynan, a writer best known for her biography of her husband, the critic Kenneth Tynan, died yesterday at King Edward VII Hospital in London. She was 57 and lived in London.

title: Mower in Accord With Western Media
description: Eric Mower & Associates in Syracuse has formed an alliance with Western International Media, the large media services agency that was recently bought by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: To Execute the Innocent Scorns Decency
description: To the Editor:

title: Park Electrochemical Corp.(PKE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Researcher Reports Evidence of a New Type of Hepatitis Virus
description: A Federal scientist said today that his team had found preliminary evidence of a new virus that is believed to cause a new type of hepatitis.

title: As Parties Skirmish Over Budget, Greenspan Offers a Painless Cure
description: As Democrats kept demanding that Republicans spell out their plans for cutting the budget, the head of the Federal Reserve Board offered them an initially painless way to do it: changing the way the Government calculates inflation.

title: No Headline
description: "This is one of the worst floods I have ever seen. First we had that terrible fire and now the land won't stop sliding. It's like Victoria Falls was coming through here." ROD STEIGER, who lives in Malibu, Calif. [ A12:4. ]

title: Duke's Krzyzewski Out for Several Weeks
description: MIKE KRZYZEWSKI was released from Duke University Hospital yesterday after being treated for back problems, but he isn't expected to coach the Blue Devils for several weeks.

title: At Newark International, Air Travelers' Tales of Woe
description: Crabby, baggy-eyed or just relieved to be home, travelers returned to Newark International Airport today, bringing tales of vacations thrown into disarray, of unwelcome detours to distant cities, of missed flights, missing baggage and misinformation.

title: Rangers, Islanders Looked To Settle
description: At least two of the three metropolitan area teams, the Rangers and the Islanders, were in favor of accepting the players' latest proposal for a new labor agreement, which was voted down yesterday by the National Hockey League's board of governors.

title: Game Time
description: Even if you maintain only a glancing acquaintance with the sports section of the newspaper, you may have heard the big news: Stephon Marbury, the top high school basketball player in the nation, has announced his decision to attend Georgia Tech next fall. This brings to an end years of speculation among hoop fans over where the prodigiously gifted young player will go. And it will surely provoke a raft of stories using Marbury's hard-earned success to illustrate how basketball can deliver talented and dedicated inner-city youth from the ghetto to stardom in college and, just maybe, a shot at the pros.

title: Tele-Metropole reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Former Housing Secretary Won't Be Charged in Investigation
description: After a five-year investigation, an independent prosecutor has decided not to bring charges against Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the head of the Department of Housing and Urban Development in the Reagan Administration and the central figure in the influence-peddling case, people following the case said today.

title: Jazz Harpist Hears a Different Drummer
description: DAPHNE HELLMAN, the jazz harpist, opened the door to her East 61st Street town house welcoming the caller to her home and life. It is a life that recalls the Katharine Hepburn genre: a stunning heiress, headstrong and original, sets about doing exactly what she wants with oblivious defiance of conventions and, of course, gets away with it and has a great time.

title: Fulfilling a Resolution With Updated Fajitas
description: FAJITAS may no longer be on the cutting edge, as they were 10 years ago, but they are still delicious. With a nip and a tuck here and there, they can fit perfectly into a New Year's resolve to eat less fat. Beef Fajitas 6 ounces flank steak 8 ounces whole onion or 7 ounces chopped ready-cut onion (1 2/3 cups) 16 ounces whole yellow and red peppers or 14 ounces ready-cut chopped peppers (4 cups) 1 teaspoon ground cumin 1/8 teaspoon salt Freshly ground black pepper 4 whole wheat no-fat tortillas, if available, or white-flour tortillas 1/2 small avocado to yield 4 small slices 1/2 cup nonfat yogurt Salsa (see recipe).

title: Executive Changes
description: DILLON, READ & COMPANY, New York, named Tamara A. Baum managing director and Raul Esquivel and Jerry Treppel senior vice presidents. FITCH INVESTORS SERVICE INC., named Frank S. Rizzo executive vice president, public finance.

title: Speaker Vallone's Education Proposal
description: Responsibility for public education in New York City is diffuse enough without heading down the path suggested by City Council Speaker Peter Vallone in his State of the City message. Mr. Vallone wants the central Board of Education expanded from seven to nine members, with the Council picking the extra two members. That would only worsen the existing clutter of appointing powers.

title: Italian Leaders Still Wrestling Coalition Crisis
description: Three weeks after the resignation of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, Italian leaders this week are inching toward a formula for an interim government to lead the country out of its political stalemate.

title: Changed Man or Not, Tom Snyder's on Late
description: In the 1970's, there were a couple of guys who turned traditional talk-show etiquette on its head. One was Stanley Siegal. The other was Tom Snyder, who, as it happens, has had his subsequently flagging career gloriously revived. Coming off a talk series on CNBC, he is now the host of CBS's new "Late Late Show" immediately after David Letterman, who years ago replaced Mr. Snyder in the slot immediately after Johnny Carson. Ain't show business grand?

title: Gingrich Knew of Comment By Historian, Her Aide Says
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich, who dismissed the House historian on Monday over her comments about an educational program on the Holocaust, knew about those statements before he hired her, an assistant to the former historian said today.

title: New Tax Cut Is Promised By Whitman
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman promised a third round of tax cuts in her first State of the State address today, but she opened at least a semantic crack in her no-new-taxes pledge by saying she needed to renew an expiring vehicle surcharge to keep a state transportation fund afloat.

title: Duke and Ament Receive '94 Honors
description: NORM DUKE, 30 of Edmond, Okla., and TONY AMENT, 25, of Garfield, N.J., were the big winners yesterday as the Professional Bowlers Association announced its awards for the 1994 player and rookie of the year respectively. (AP)

title: Sylvia B. Seaman, 94, a Writer and a Suffragist
description: Sylvia Bernstein Seaman, a writer and one of the last active members of the suffragist movement, died on Sunday at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 94.

title: Keith McDaniel, 38, Principal Dancer With Ailey Troupe
description: Keith McDaniel, a principal dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and on Broadway, died on Jan. 2 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 38.

title: EXX
description: Class A shares of EXX Inc. surged yesterday after it reported a preliminary tripling of both sales and profit for the fourth quarter. The company, which makes toys based on the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers, will release final figures in March.

title: Seagate Technology Inc.(SGAT,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: Seagate Technology said that its results for the six months ended Dec. 30, included a one-time write-off of in-process research and development of $ 43 million incurred in connection with the August acquisition of data protection software developer Palindrome Corp. Without the write-off and its related tax effects, the company said its net income for the period would have been $ 1.99 a share.

title: Majority Backs Cigarette Rules, Poll by Tobacco Industry Finds
description: The lobbying arm of the tobacco industry released a poll today with a finding that runs counter to its position: a majority of Americans think increased Government regulation of cigarettes is important.

title: New Site Proposed for Dioxin-Tainted Sand
description: Backing off a much-criticized plan to dump 150,000 tons of dioxin-tainted sand a half mile off Coney Island, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is now proposing to deposit the material in an underwater pit three miles from Staten Island.

title: Official Quits AT&T to Run Netscape
description: The head of AT&T's cellular telephone and paging division is resigning only four months after joining the company to become chief executive of a small California company that makes Internet software.

title: Burlington Resources Inc.(BR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,138,000, or 1 cent a share.Burlington Resources said that the latest quarter included a $ 54,757,000 income tax benefit, compared with a $ 8,410,000 benefit in the year-ago period. The company had a $ 1,938,000 loss from continuing operations before the benefit in the latest quarter, compared with income of $ 43,638,000 in same period a year ago.In fiscal 1994, the company's tax benefit totaled $ 63,977,000, compared with income tax expense of $ 52,264,000 a year ago. Income from continuing operations before income taxes for fiscal 1994 totaled $ 90,269,000, against $ 307,438,000 a year ago.Burlington Resources said that its capital expenditures increased to $ 882 million from $ 553 million a year ago, reflecting expanded development activity and reserve acquisitions.

title: Developments in Congress
description: HOUSE: Dozens of lawmaker gathered on Capitol Hill to demonstrate their support for term limits, papering over deep divisions over what the lmit should be. The star attraction was Speaker Newt Gingrich, who is beginning his ninth term - his 17th year - in Congress. Mr. Gingrich said he favored a 12-year limit and would vote against the six-year limit that a new Republican poll shows most voters favoring. "A six-year learning curve is just too short," he said. "I don't know that I'm all that smart, but as hard as I worked at it, I didn't get it in the firstr six year." Most of the 73 freshman Republicans support the six-year limit.

title: The Old Gang Gathers to Remember Tip O'Neill
description: They were there when Tip O'Neill went to grammar school. They were there when he went to Congress, in 1953, and when he became Speaker, in 1977, and when he retired, in 1987.

title: Mix-Ups and Worse Arising from Sex-Offender Notification
description: Dennis Hoffman had been a good worker at Daniel Enderle's construction company before he was arrested six years ago. So when he was released from state prison on Tuesday, Mr. Enderle agreed to give him a ride from jail to his sister's house.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Associates Corp. of North America, Dallas, is selling $300 million of 8.125 notes due in 1998 through UBS Securities Inc. The notes are priced at 99.676 to yield 8.25 percent. The issue is noncallable and rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corp. and Duff & Phelps.

title: Roderick Stephens, 85, Sailor And Innovator in Yacht Design
description: Roderick Stephens Jr., a leading yachtsman and boat systems expert who sailed in three America's Cup defense campaigns, died early Tuesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 85.

title: AT HOME WITH: Larry Kramer; When a Roaring Lion Learns to Purr
description: THEY are two words that stab fear in a bureaucrat's heart, send doctors groping for Alka-Seltzer and television producers begging for mercy. They inspire tight-lipped secretaries to insist that their bosses are in a meeting, out to lunch, on safari.

title: End Duty-Free Limit In New Trade Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about cooperation between the Peace Corps and the International Rescue Committee misstated the new relationship. Some Peace Corps volunteers, not the entire federal agency, will be placed under the direction of the Rescue Committee, a private group.

title: Sofia Journal; Rogue 'Wrestlers' Have an Armlock on Bulgaria
description: In the Vienna Cafe at one of this city's most expensive hotels, the clientele is mainly men. They are sturdily built, carry mobile phones and lend a menacing air to the art nouveau decor.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10 CHECHEN SEEKS PEACE The president of secessionist Chechnya, Dzhokhar M. Dudayev, conceded today that it could not win its war with Russia and urged talks with Russian leaders. A1

description: Accentuating the Positive, 'Little Prince' Without a Snake Theaterworks/USA Promenade Theater

title: Escapee Killed; 2 Are Captured
description: Acting on information from two homeless men seeking a reward, law-enforcement officers killed one escapee from a state prison and captured another late Tuesday at an encampment of shanties near here. A third fugitive was taken into custody tonight as he walked in the city's Little Havana section.

title: Christopher Said to Offer to Quit, but Clinton Says No
description: In a private meeting with President Clinton at the White House before Christmas, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said he wanted to resign but Mr. Clinton said he wanted Mr. Christopher to stay in his post indefinitely, according to senior Administration officials and outsiders familiar with the conversation.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Moves to Increase Aid To Ease Crisis in Mexico

title: No Headline
description: "New York wants to get rid of a killer. We want him to be returned to be executed. I think anyone who takes a life in a premeditated fashion should lose his own." -- GOV. FRANK KEATING of Oklahoma. [ B8:1. ]

title: Seasoned Helmsmen Feeling Unprepared
description: Call it weather, or call it calamity, but uneasiness has set the stage here for the start of the first set of America's Cup defender trials on Thursday.

title: Croatia Is Set to End Mandate Of U.N. Force on Its Territory
description: President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, exasperated by the continued Serbian occuption of large swaths of his country, has decided to end the mandate of United Nations forces in Croatia on March 31, Western diplomats said today.

title: Mr. Pataki's Mediocre Choices
description: No one wins a hard-fought race for governor by promising, publicly at least, that important state jobs will be handed out to key political supporters. Still, it is not all that surprising, or unusual, that Gov. George Pataki of New York would sprinkle his new administration with political appointees even though their resumes are fairly thin. Two of Mr. Pataki's latest choices, however, stretch political loyalty too far.

title: Yeltsin Weighs a Shake-Up Of Russian Army Command
description: In a further sign of growing dissatisfaction with how the divided and demoralized Russian military has handled the military offensive in Chechnya, President Boris N. Yeltsin was reported today to be considering taking over direct control of Russia's armed forces.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AQUILA GAS PIPELINE CORP., San Antonio, a provider of natural gas, agreed to acquire Tristar Gas Co., Dallas, a closely held natural gas company, for $16.3 million.

title:
Houses by Gates: Virtual and Real;
Welcome to Bob's Place, Where No Icon's a Stranger
description: THE first image on the computer screen is a bright brass knocker on a red door. Click. A living room appears, a fire blazing happily in the hearth. Outside the picture windows, snow-capped mountains rise. In the corner is a grandfather clock; on the carpet, a tawny cat. On the coffee table are a Rolodex file, a checkbook and a home maintenance guide. Click. The wall calendar tells you today's the day to clean the chimney. Click. The maintenance guide tells you how.

title: Houses by Gates: Virtual and Real; It Takes Time To Build Xanadu
description: THE garage is tunneled into the hillside, with room enough to hold 20 cars, its roof covered by sod from the Cascade Range and surrounded by a fresh-planted forest of Northwest alders. Batman would blush.

title: City Ballet's Rustic Romp
description: In the search for genius, mere excellence is never enough. It is easy to say that David Allan's "Pastoral Dances," which were performed by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday night, were not the equivalent of a masterpiece by George Balanchine. But it is equally defeating to overlook excellence on its own terms, which is what "Pastoral Dances" embody so effortlessly

title: Bridge
description: Many generations of New York players will mourn the loss of Victor Mitchell, who died in Manhattan last Thursday at age 71. He was a Runyonesque figure with a generous heart who liked to attend the races at Aqueduct.

title: ICF Kaiser International Inc.(ICF,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Before preferred stock dividends and accretion. The company reported preferred stock dividends and accretion of $ 539,000 for the third quarter and $ 1,616,000 for the 9 months.c-Net income and before preferred stock dividends and accretion. The company reported preferred stock dividends and accretion of $ 1,309,000 for the quarter and $ 3,972,000 for the 9 months.(Loss)

title: Marshall & Ilsley Corp.(MRIS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After merger-related gain of $ 11,009,000. Before item, net income was $ 47,464,000, or 48 cents a primary share.c-After merger-related items including a $ 76 million charge and $ 12.2 million in gains. Before items, net income was $ 169,859,000, or $ 1.71 a primary share.Year-ago figures are restated for a merger with Valley Bancorp.

title: Argentina Striving To Regain Confidence
description: As Mexico's financial crisis continues, and markets around Latin America are jolted, Argentina has been hit hardest among the Latin nations.

title: NEW AIDS FINDINGS ON WHY DRUGS FAIL
description: New findings about how the AIDS virus behaves in the body help explain why all drugs tried until now have been ineffective, and they cast new light on the reaction of the body's immune system to the invader.

title: Police Sift Clues in $5 Million Jewelry Theft
description: Police officials said yesterday that they were still interviewing three people who said they were robbed of $5 million in jewelry when they pulled their car over after an accident on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.

title: HALLMARK TO REFOCUS MARKETING OF GREETING CARDS
description: Hallmark Cards Inc. said yesterday that it would place a greater emphasis on selling its greeting cards through mass merchandisers. Retailing analysts said Hallmark was responding to competitive pressures and changing buying patterns. Jeffrey S. Stein, and analyst at McDonald & Company, said that more than 90 percent of greetings cards were bought by women, and that working women were increasingly doing one-stop shopping in discount and drug stores rather than in Hallmark specialty stores. Irvine O. Hockaday, chief executive of the closely held company, said the new focus could result in work-force reductions, but he said layoffs were not planned. Hallmark, based in Kansas City, Mo., has about 21,000 employees.

title: Christopher Asks Out But Clinton Says No
description: In a private meeting with President Clinton at the White House last month, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said he wanted to resign, but Mr. Clinton said he wanted Mr. Christopher to stay in his post indefinitely, according to senior Administration officials and outsiders familiar with the conversation.

title: JOHN HANCOCK TO LAY OFF 10% OF WORK FORCE IN BOSTON
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it would lay off 10 percent of its work force, or 460 employees, at its headquarters in Boston as part of a cost-cutting effort to save $100 million annually. The company, the nation's ninth-largest life insurer, said the cuts would begin in February and be completed in the next 12 months. John Hancock, which cut 500 jobs in 1991, said the current plan would reduce its headquarters staff to about 10,420. In addition, John Hancock said it would cut an unspecified number of its 4,000 to 5,000 sales agents in offices across the country.

title: Dr. Alfred Lilienfeld; Psychiatrist Was 88
description: Dr. Alfred Lilienfeld, a Manhattan psychiatrist and expert on psychosomatic illness, died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 88 and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: Manitowoc Co.(MTW,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income(Loss)Year-ago periods ended Jan. 1, 1994.The company said its net loss included a pretax plant consolidation charge of $ 14 million, or $ 1.12 a share. The charge included a write-down of the facility being abandoned and estimated holding costs while the plant is being marketed.

title: Bally Gaming Sale Plan Rejected by Regulators
description: A Louisiana gambling commission has rejected a bid by Bally Gaming Inc. to sell slot machines to a planned casino in the state, after finding that the company's management and directors had allowed it to be infiltrated by "elements of organized crime".

title: State Democratic Chairmen Criticize Dodd as Too Liberal
description: President Clinton's choice of Senator Christopher J. Dodd to head the Democratic National Committee has sparked an open rebellion among some state party leaders who argue that he is too liberal and that he cannot effectively represent the interests of his home state and lead the national party at the same time.

title: 2 New Accounts Gained by Grey
description: The Whitehall-Robins Healthcare division of the American Home Products Corporation added Grey Advertising in New York to its agency roster yesterday by naming Grey to handle its Anacin pain-reliever and Chapstick lip care brands, with combined billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million. For the last three years, the Anacin account has been at McCann-Erickson New York and the Chapstick account at Avrett, Free & Ginsberg in New York.

title: Mexico's Crisis Drags Down U.S. Stocks
description: To traders, the peso loomed larger than inflation yesterday. The stock market rallied for all of 10 minutes because of a report showing moderate inflation. But the continuing financial crisis in Mexico quickly dragged down stock prices as traders wondered which American companies would be hurt by the declining peso.

title: Seahawks Expected to Name Erickson
description: DENNIS ERICKSON of the University of Miami has been hired as coach of the Seattle Seahawks, The Associated Press reported last night. The Seahawks have called a news conference for today in Palo Alto, Calif., apparently to announce the hiring, which came after a week of negotiations.

title: Premier Bancorp Inc.(PRBC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 44,322,000, or $ 1.38 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Premier Bancorp said that prior-period results were restated to include the acquisition of Heritage Financial Corp. in June 1994.The decrease in operating earnings for the latest quarter and year primarily was attributable to increased noninterest expense largely due to acquisitions and acquisition-related charges. Provisions made for severance pay for staff reductions in acquired banks and for disposition costs for excess facilities and equipment of acquired banks contributed to the increase.Merit increases, expenses related to opening new branch facilities, higher ad valorem taxes and marketing expenses also contributed to the increase in noninterest expense.The company also said that contributing to the decline in operating earnings for both periods was an increase in income tax expense reflecting the higher level of taxable income earned in 1994.Additionally, the company's income tax expense in 1993 included a $ 1.1 million benefit derived from recording an increase in the net deferred tax asset to reflect the increase in the corporate tax rate to 35 percent from 34 percent.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Mexico's Financial Crisis The Clinton Administration stepped up efforts to help Mexico, saying it was ready to increase a $9 billion line of credit. It is also looking for ways to provide subsidized loans to Mexico. [ Page D1. ] The peso and the Mexican stock market gained after two days of steep losses, helped by the indication of U.S. support. [ D6. ]

title:
CHAMPIONSHIPS;
Chargers Move to Block Out Distractions
description: The Chargers today abandoned a practice field that had become a river of mud for a somewhat drier field at Jack Murphy Stadium, where they held their first full practice of the week to the sound of crowd noise booming from loudspeakers.

description: To the Editor:

title: Independent Ski Resorts Go for Diversity
description: Recent mergers among ski resorts have set up corporate galaxies that reach out to skiers with deals that are light years away from anything most single resorts can afford. But in an effort to strike back, other ski areas are doing some celestial thinking of their own.

title: New Galactic Evidence of Black Holes
description: A gigantic concentration of mass, equivalent to 40 million Suns, has been detected at the heart of a distant galaxy. It is a region of incredible turbulence, surrounded by a maelstrom of gas and dust, generating powerful X-rays and twisted jets of gas emerging at speeds of 400 miles a second. It is almost certainly a black hole.

title: Police Charge a Second Suspect In Six Killings in College Point
description: Acting on an anonymous tip, the police made a second arrest yesterday in the killings last week of six people in College Point, Queens, but a third suspect remained at large and investigators had yet to determine the motive for the massacre.

title: Treasury Issues Are Up On New Price Report
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday for the second consecutive session after another report showing moderate inflation.

title: Blame for the Cold War Falls on the Soviet Side
description: Those on the political right who have been inveighing against the leftish tendencies of PBS documentaries can find solace in "Messengers From Moscow," an account of the cold war that echoes decades of messages from Washington that Soviet ambitions were behind the long East-West confrontation.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Saturday about activities marking the 30th anniversary of the playwright Lorraine Hansberry's death misidentified the play of hers that will be performed at Ford's Theater in Washington on Feb. 10. It is "A Raisin in the Sun," not "To Be Young, Gifted and Black."

title: Essay; Most Sacred Cow
description: Across the street and down the block, a languid construction gang is renovating the Department of Veterans Affairs. When finished, entrenched bureaucrats will have a magnificent view of the White House from Vermont Avenue at a cost of $43 million.

title: A 1993 Rebellion Simmers in Caucasus
description: Across the border from Chechnya, another Caucasus separatist movement threatens to reignite in Georgia, where talks between the central Government and the breakaway region of Abkhazia are stalled, a report from Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali says.

title: Pact Reached For Salvaging Hockey Season
description: On the 103d day of a bitter lockout, the representatives for National Hockey League players and owners said yesterday that they had reached a tentative collective bargaining agreement, that training camps would probably open by tomorrow and that a truncated 48-game season would probably start late next week.

description: Willis Reed stood at one end of Byrne Meadowlands Arena today, expounding on the nuances of acting like a co-captain. Derrick Coleman sat on his locker-room stool on the other end of the arena, explaining that he has to "take care of Derrick," not the Nets.

title: A Warmer Tone From the Mayor
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani used his State of the City address yesterday in a way that does him credit and augurs well for the second year of his term. He publicly declared a truce in the budget warfare that has poisoned his relations with the City Council and contributed to New York City's fiscal anxieties.

title: S.E.C. Wins Big Round Against Stratton Oakmont Firm
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission won an important round yesterday in its continuing court battle against Stratton Oakmont, a Long Island brokerage firm that the commission had accused of operating as a penny-stock boiler room.

description: An approach is made, and Charles Haley deflects it the way he pushes aside an offensive lineman.

title: Algerian Opposition Says It Is Near Agreement on a Peace Plan
description: Representatives of major Algerian opposition parties, including Muslim fundamentalists battling the country's Government, said today that they were close to a joint proposal for a cease-fire and a transitional government to end the Algerian civil war.

description: To the Editor:

description: Revenue represented gross revenues.

title: Market Place; Despite the turmoil in Mexico, some companies have seen gains.
description: IN the rubble of the Mexican stock market, it has been almost impossible to make dollars by owning Mexican stocks. Only one large company has seen its value rise enough in pesos to offset that currency's collapse against the dollar since its first devaluation on Dec. 19.

title: Brother Cadfael on the Case
description: Public television's "Mystery" is taking an unusual detour, going back to the 12th century for a series of four 90-minute stories about Cadfael, a Benedictine monk and amazingly busy sleuth. Portrayed by Derek Jacobi, the character is the hero in a series of best-selling novels by Ellis Peters, pen name for Edith Pargeter, now over 80 and still turning out Cadfael tales.

title: Eh? C.F.L. Is Putting a Team in Alabama
description: A Canadian Football League team landed in Alabama yesterday, thanks to the owner, ART WILLIAMS, a former insurance executive, who is personally funding the franchise with $10 million and has signed a 10-year lease at Legion Field in Birmingham.

title: A Pay Raise's Impact
description: The Clinton Administration, which appears to be advocating a higher minimum wage as one of its major policy objectives, is doing so at a time when most economists find less damage from raising the minimum wage than they once did.

title: Storage Space Becomes a Floating Landscape
description: SARA KLAR is a painter and interior designer. When Cary and Donna Park wanted storage for their bedroom in their Manhattan apartment, Ms. Klar gave them an inventive landscape of silvery hanging cabinets more than 14 1/2 feet long.

title: George Aguirre, 62, Hispanic-Art Backer
description: George L. Aguirre, a pioneer of laser photography and an advocate of Hispanic culture in New York City, died here on Sunday. He was 62.

title: B.A.T. TO TRIM JOBS AT AMERICAN TOBACCO
description: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, the United States subsidiary of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. of Britain, said yesterday that it would cut as many as 1,680 sales, administrative and research jobs as it consolidates the operations of the American Tobacco Company. B.A.T. bought American Tobacco last month from American Brands Inc. and merged it with Brown & Williamson, based in Louisville, Ky. Brown & Williamson said yesterday that it had laid off about 1,230 full-time sales employees, of which 150 would be offered part-time positions. The company plans to eliminate another 450 research and administrative support jobs by phasing out American Tobacco operations in Chester, Va., and Stamford, Conn. Some of those employees will be offered new positions, the company said.

title: New Study of Electromagnetism Clouds Hunt for Cancer Link
description: In a study that further muddies the issue of whether electrical transmission lines affect human health, researchers have found that electric utility workers exposed to high levels of magnetic radiation face a greater risk of dying from brain cancer than workers exposed to lower levels. But no general association was found between exposure to the radiation and deaths from leukemia.

title: CD-ROM Deal on Language
description: Random House Inc. and Syracuse Language systems are teaming up to jointly publish a series of language instruction programs on CD-ROM's under the Living Language Multimedia imprint, which can trace its origins to language instruction on records nearly a half-century ago.

title: Agency Lifts Restriction on Use of Plane in Cold Weather
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today lifted a ban on flying in icy conditions that it imposed one month ago on the type of plane that crashed in October near Roselawn, Ind., killing 68 people.

title: For American Corporations, a Tie That Binds Too Tightly
description: These days, Mexico's troubles are increasingly becoming the United States'.

title: House Committee Advances Balanced-Budget Measure
description: The House nudged a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution a step closer to enactment today, and the Senate passed its first bill, a measure subjecting Congress to the same labor laws that govern private employment.

title: Tigers' New Executive: All in the Family
description: JOHN McHALE Jr. returned to his Detroit roots yesterday when he was named the 14th president and chief executive officer of the Tigers, the team his father, JOHN McHALE, once served as a player and general manager and his second cousin, WALTER BRIGGS Jr., once headed.

title: Mayor to Shift Oversight Role For City Cabs
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his Police Commissioner, William J. Bratton, have said again and again that the police will go after seemingly minor annoyances that affect the "quality of life" in New York -- like overly aggressive beggars and windshield-smearing squeegee men.

title: U.S., in Shift, Says Russia Breaks Pacts
description: After weeks of saying Russia's assault against Chechnya was strictly an internal matter, the Clinton Administration accused Moscow today of violating international agreements by failing to notify other countries about its large-scale troop movements into Chechnya.

title: M. Allen Pond, 82, Public Health Expert
description: M. Allen Pond, who was an Assistant Surgeon General of the United States in the 1960's and later the dean of the School of Public Health at the University of Pittsburgh, died last Wednesday at his home in Cranberry Township, Pa. He was 82.

title: Northeast Federal Corp.(NSB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss(Loss)As previously announced, Northeast Federal signed a definitive agreement for its acquisition by Shawmut National Corp.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Washing Away Scale

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about redevelopment plans for the Arverne area of the Rockaways in Queens misstated the given name of the managing partner of Washington Square Partners, a development company. He is Paul Travis, not Peter.

title: Economic Scene; Mexico's lesson: don't depend on the kindness of foreign investors.
description: TO judge by the press reviews, Mexico's economic reformers did everything right. Why then did the peso collapse?

title: CHRONICLE
description: MILTON MOLLEN, 74, for whom New York City's commission to investigate police corruption was named, is back in the private practice of law after a 42-year hiatus. He has joined Graubard Mollen Horowitz Pomeranz & Shapiro, the firm of his son, SCOTT MOLLEN.

title: Hanoi to Accept Refugees Now in Germany in Exchange for Aid
description: Germany said today that it would soon begin forcibly repatriating some of the 40,000 Vietnamese immigrants here illegally, and that Hanoi agreed to accept them by 2000 in exchange for increased trade and economic aid.

title: A Death, Yet Another, in Grozny
description: Marya Semyonovna was found dead this morning in Grozny. She was buried by her neighbors in a shallow ditch they dug in the courtyard of their bombed apartment building at 103 Lenin Prospekt.

title: New York Transfers Killer to Oklahoma To Await Execution
description: Thomas J. Grasso, the double murderer who has demanded to be executed and whose case became an issue in George E. Pataki's gubernatorial campaign, was transferred today from New York to Oklahoma to await execution.

title: MOGUL HOMES
description: In 1895, when locomotives drove the American economy, a railroad scion named George Washington Vanderbilt built the ultimate bachelor pad: a 175,000-square-foot chateau with 225 rooms. It remains the largest home in the United States. A century later, microchips rule, and Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft, and his wife are settling for just 34,000 square feet, most of it underground. The number of rooms? Who knows? Their architects aren't talking. Given inflation (and considering the wall-to-wall high-tech gadgetry that is being installed), the Gates house will probably be up to the mogul standard set by Biltmore -- costing around $30 million. So if you ever strike it rich, here's a primer to kingpin style. MITCHELL OWENS

title: Primadonna Resorts
description: Shares of Primadonna Resorts, an operator of casino-hotels, fell yesterday. After the market closed on Tuesday, the company said that fourth-quarter earnings were likely to be below estimates.

description: Architecture and Design Main waiting room, Grand Central Terminal, Park Avenue at 42d Street; (212)753-1722.

description: b-Included a $ 17.3 million noncash, nonrecurring gain on the exchange of about 94 percent of the company's exchangeable preferred stock for shares of Little Switzerland Inc. common stock.

title: Suntrust Banks Inc.(STI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dollar Gains Against Mark As Peseta and Lira Recover
description: The dollar rose against the German mark yesterday as turmoil in European markets abated, easing demand for marks.

title: Passing the Torch: A special report.; New Israeli Generation: 'Me' Replaces Myths
description: An important generational change is under way in Israel's public life, and with it has come a change in what Israelis care about and demand from their leaders.

title: Ex-Salomon Chief Stalled
description: The former chief executive of Salomon Inc., John H. Gutfreund, has lost a court bid to void an arbitration panel's decision denying his $56.3 million claim against the company.

title: In Performance; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Taming a Noisy Intruder In the Quiet Chamber World New York Philharmonic Ensembles Merkin Concert Hall

title: Republicans' Philosophical Discord Stalls Plan for Changes
description: Negotiations over the future of the nation's welfare programs have been slowed by the emergence of deep philosophical disagreements between Republican governors and Republican members of Congress.

title: Chinese Runner Wants Out of 'Ma Army'
description: WANG JUNXIA, China's top female long-distance runner, has vowed not to return to training under MA JUNREN, complaining that the controversial coach treated his athletes poorly.

title: City Rejects 2 More Bidders for Municipal Concrete Plant
description: New York City officials have rejected proposals by two companies to take over a city-subsidized concrete plant on the West Side, creating fresh doubts about its future and about how municipal construction projects in Manhattan will get concrete supplies this year.

title: Storms Drench California, Creating a Trail of Havoc
description: A major winter storm system continued to push out of the Pacific Ocean today after causing tens of millions of dollars in flood damage to roads, homes, businesses and crops, and leaving Californians bracing for a renewal of heavy rainfall on Friday.

title: Embattled Borland Chief Steps Down
description: A self-described "barbarian" of the software industry has fallen on his sword, a victim of both his own missteps and the increasingly brutal market for personal computer business software.

title: Executive Changes
description: BROWN BROTHERS HARRIMAN & CO., New York, named Radford W. Klotz a general partner. HASBRO INC., Pawtucket, R.I., appointed Dave Wilson president of the newly formed Hasbro Group, an umbrella organization that will manage the company's two domestic game companies: Milton Bradley Co. and Parker Brothers.

title: Miami Is Now 1-29 On the Road
description: While Miami guard Steven Edwards cried tears of joy, St. John's players just cried. Embarrassment and disbelief were the prevailing emotions after the Miami Hurricanes did what few expected by stunning St. John's, 82-79, last night at Alumni Hall.

title: Coaches Reward Nebraska's Osborne
description: TOM OSBORNE added another honor to Nebraska's national-championship season when he was named 1994 National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I-A coach of the year yesterday at the American Football Coaches Association convention in Dallas. The coaching body's award was the first in Osborne's 22 seasons at Nebraska, which beat Miami, 24-17, in the Orange Bowl to complete a 13-0 season.

title: Absence of Salary Cap In Settlement Heartens Baseball Union Leaders
description: Donald Fehr, in Arizona, and Gene Orza, in New York, had the same reaction yesterday to the settlement of the National Hockey League labor dispute, picking out the same refrain they have heard countless times from baseball owners.

title: Freeze Poultry but Don't Call It Fresh, U.S. Says
description: After 60 years of allowing frozen chicken and turkey to be sold as fresh, the Department of Agriculture said today that it had decided that the practice was deceptive and proposed that thawed frozen poultry be labeled as "previously frozen."

title: Nomination Earns Pataki Hot Water In 2 States
description: GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI may be running into more criticism than he anticipated with his nomination of George J. Marlin, a Conservative Party leader with no government experience, to head the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Former executive directors of the authority are highly critical of Mr. Marlin, and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, unimpressed with the choice, is twitting her New York counterpart. She was apparently not consulted in advance and was informed by fax, both breaches of political etiquette.

title: Anti-Gay Measure Is Defeated
description: In the latest skirmish of a national battle over laws guaranteeing rights of homosexuals, voters in West Palm Beach, Fla., upheld an anti-discrimination ordinance in a special election on Tuesday.

title: Mercury Finance Co.(MFN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Barney Frank's Delivery
description: To the Editor:

title: TCF Financial Corp.(TCB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 7,894,000, or 63 cents a share, from the acquisition of Republic Capital Group Inc.Credit loss provisions in the latest periods totaled $ 51,331,000 in the quarter and $ 194,228,000 in the year, compared with credit loss provisions of $ 44,194,000 and $ 162,491,000 in the year-ago peirods, respectively.

title: Tension at Convention Over Restructuring Issue
description: The delegates were getting antsy. Their annual effort to shape college sports was coming to an end. A motion was made to limit debate on each remaining issue to five minutes. The motion was defeated, but the point had been made. Red-eye reservations were waiting and the promise of more storms provided a very good reason for leaders of higher education to get out of town and back to their campuses.

title: Captive Thai Women Suffered Physical Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Twyla Tharp Discovers Virtue as a Cause for Dancing
description: The title doesn't roll easily off the tongue. Is anything about Twyla Tharp -- the wise-cracking Roseanne of the dance world and one of its pre-eminent and most provocative choreographers -- ever easy? But "Twyla Tharp Red, White and Blues New Works," a revue that opens on Monday for a two-week run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, was the product of a very simple desire.

title: Rangers and Islanders Make Ticket Plans, but Devils Don't
description: With no actual schedule to work from, Rangers and Islanders ticket officials were flying blind -- and in different directions -- in the wake of yesterday's tentative collective bargaining agreement. Devils officials were not flying at all.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT PREDICTS 8 PERCENT RISE IN EARNINGS
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that it expected to report an 8 percent increase in earnings last year on rising sales of its health care products. Warner-Lambert, based in Morris Plains, N.J., predicted earnings of about $700 million for 1994, before extraordinary charges and accounting adjustments, compared with $645 million, or $4.78 a share, in 1993. The company's worldwide sales are expected to rise 11 percent, to $6.4 billion, from $5.8 billion in 1993. Warner-Lambert, whose products include Listerine, Benadryl and Rolaids, said it would announce its final 1994 results on Jan. 24. The company's shares fell $1.25, to $74.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Agassi Loses in Exhibition's First Round Patrick Rafter was a 6-3, 6-2 winner over Andre Agassi yesterday in the first round of the Adelaide International, an exhibition and warm-up to the Australian Open. "It was very tough for me to see and I struggled a lot in that twilight," said Agassi, who will make his Australian Open debut next week. Guy Forget scored another upset, defeating Todd Martin, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6 (7-4). (AP) Sampras Struggles but Wins: Pete Sampras, the world's top-ranked player, defeated Wally Masur, 6-1, 4-6, 6-1, in the first round of the Colonial Classic, an eight-man exhibition in Melbourne, Australia. Stefan Edberg, who won last week's event in Doha, Qatar, beat Michael Stich, 6-2, 6-4. Boris Becker and Michael Chang beat Australian opponents to advance to the other semifinal. Becker beat Jason Stoltenberg, 6-4, 6-2, and Chang defeated Pat Cash, 6-2, 6-4. (AP)

title: Journal; Separated at Birth
description: Was it last week's photo of those huge heads side by side at the White House, each gleaming with the identical Doublemint smile? Or was it the new Speaker's compassionate opening address to the House in which he felt poor people's pain? Or was it the television debut of Kathleen Gingrich, colorfully strong-willed Middle American Mom, who is as unapologetic about her cigarette addiction as the late, great Virginia Kelley was about her two-dollar bets?

title: Jobless Data Show Blacks Joining Economic Recovery
description: Unlike other economic recoveries in which blacks were often left behind, the current upswing helped push the unemployment rate for blacks to below 10 percent last month for the first time in more than two decades.

title: Kennedy Honors Gave Artists Their Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Year Of Little Rise In Inflation
description: Despite fears of inflation that have dominated economic policy in the last year, consumer prices for 1994 rose only 2.7 percent, the fourth consecutive year in which inflation failed to advance any more than 3 percent or so, the Government said today.

description: To the Editor:

title: The House That's So, So . . . Mary
description: EVAN and NAOMI MAURER had no idea they had bought a house haunted by a celebrity ghost when they moved from Michigan to Minnesota. Never mind that the spirit of Mary Richards was the friendliest specter since Casper; the spooking began immediately. "This house, Mary's house, turned out to be Minnesota's version of Graceland," Mr. Maurer said recently. "Who knew?"

title: CHRONICLE
description: What would a day be without word of the British royal family? DIANA, THE PRINCESS OF WALES, is expected to be in New York for the 14th annual awards ceremony of the Council of Fashion Designers of America on Jan. 30 at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Valerie Cossart, 87, Actress of the 30's
description: Valerie Cossart, an actress who appeared in many Broadway and Off Broadway productions in the 1930's and 40's, died on Dec. 31 at Beth Israel North Hospital in Manhattan. She was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

description: In percent

title: The Future of U.N. Peacekeeping
description: United Nations peacekeeping missions have hit hard times. Since the end of the cold war, the use of lightly armed soldiers to police cease-fires or monitor elections has given way to ambitious attempts to impose peace on hostile forces determined to keep fighting, as in Somalia or Bosnia.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday, about two technologies competing to become the industry standard for digital videodisks, referred incorrectly in some editions to the operas of Wagner's "Ring" cycle, cited as an example of storage capacity. They are a group of four operas, not a trilogy.

title: Israelis and Arabs Back Regional Bank
description: The Clinton Administration's push for a regional development bank in the Middle East moved ahead today when Israel, Egypt, Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization jointly proposed to set it up..

title: Clarcor Inc.(CLC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a net gain of 2 cents a share which comprises a gain of $ 3.2 million, or 21 cents a share, from sale of stock in an affiliate, and nonrecurring write-offs of $ 2.8 million, or 19 cents a share, from ''rationalization'' of selected manufacturing facilities, machinery and personnel costs, in the quarter and year. The year was also after an accounting gain of $ 630,000, or 4 cents a share, from the adoption of FASB 109.Clarcor said that excluding the nonrecurring items, it had net income of $ 6.8 million, or 46 cents a share, in the latest fourth quarter, and operating income of $ 20.3 million, or $ 1.37 a share, in the latest year.

title: Clinton Is Confident U.S. Trade Deficit With Japan Will Narrow
description: After two years of confrontational meetings with a succession of Japanese leaders, President Clinton changed his tone today, expressing confidence that his Administration's blitz of recent accords with Tokyo would soon bring down the United States' $60 billion trade deficit with Japan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sometimes there's still happy news from royal families, even those without thrones.

title: House Republicans Hit a Snag Over the Extent of Term Limits
description: The new members of the week-old 104th Congress, who rode into town on a wave of anti-Congress sentiment, have found themselves at odds with longer-sitting members over how long they should all stay.

title: Intel Settles A Legal Duel With Rival
description: The Intel Corporation and Advanced Micro Devices Inc. ended their bitter, seven-year legal fight today, settling all court disputes over whether Advanced Micro Devices had the right to make copies of Intel's industry-dominating microprocessor chip.

description: Baseball American League

title: In With the New at the Winter Antiques Show
description: ONE thing you can count on: when the 41st Winter Antiques Show opens on Jan. 20 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, it will be unlike any others before it.

title: Biogen's Share Price Drops In a Running Patent Battle
description: Firing a volley in a war over biotechnology patents, Schering A.G., the German drug maker, said yesterday that it had been awarded exclusive rights to a process being used by Biogen Inc. The announcement sent shares of Biogen tumbling.

title: Southtrust Corp.(SOTR,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Best Deal in Town
description: President Clinton's proposed $10,000-a-year tax deduction for college tuition reopens issues about how our society finances higher education, and about who receives subsidies. Virtually everyone now agrees that able but poor students should be granted scholarships; few realize that America's public universities have also become a vehicle for upper-middle-class entitlement.

title: Don't Look Now, but Knicks Are Bonding
description: Who said the Knicks would be lost without Charles Oakley? Who said New York needed shooting guards who can shoot? Who said the Knicks looked old and tired?

title: Death Foes See 2 Slim Chances To Prevent Execution of Grasso
description: Opponents of capital punishment said today that there might be a way to challenge the execution of Thomas J. Grasso in Oklahoma, but they said the chances of success were remote.

title: Michael Castaldi, 90, Ex-Special Prosecutor, Dies
description: Michael A. Castaldi, a former New York City special prosecutor and State Supreme Court justice, died on Monday at the Heartland Health Care Center in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. A former resident of Flushing, Queens, he was 90 and lived in Jupiter, Fla.

title: End Is Sought To Blood Test That Barred Many Donors
description: A Federal panel recommended today that blood banks stop performing a screening test introduced in 1987 that has permanently excluded about one million people as blood donors in this country, even though many are healthy. The exclusions contribute to the nation's severe blood shortage.

title: Hunting Fistfuls Of Bounty Dollars; An Unusual Freelance Career: Capturing Convicted Aliens
description: The final leg of Lennox Medina's aborted flight from justice was a 12-story elevator ride up to the Immigration and Naturalization Service's deportation office in Manhattan. After 18 hours spent in handcuffs and in silence, the 30-year-old native of Trinidad and convicted felon began to swear and to threaten violence. And then he began to cry.

title: McMillen Looks Back on 70 Years of the Grand and the Grander
description: BETTY SHERRILL, the president of McMillen, the interior design company that just celebrated 70 years in business (Mrs. Sherrill has been there since 1951), is one person from whom name-dropping can be, well, charming. On a tour of pictures of projects and clients that were on display in the offices on East 56th Street in November and December, she came upon a photograph of a young Rose Kennedy and said, "Isn't she cute?" She continued: "There's Jean Nidetch, the diet queen; Her Majesty Queen Noor of Jordan; Babe Paley; Mary Phipps as a Gibson girl; Marjorie Merriweather Post; Diana Ross and her children, and Olive Watson of I.B.M. And over there, Alice Walton, Sam's only daughter -- that's Wal-Mart."

title: Highsmith Starting New Career in Boxing
description: The former National Football League running back ALONZO HIGHSMITH, whose three-year career ended with a 1992 knee injury, is back in pro sports -- as a heavyweight boxer. Highsmith, the No. 3 pick in the 1987 N.F.L. draft, has been training in Houston for a year and is scheduled to make his ring debut on a card in that city Feb. 23.

description: Per share amounts have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split distrbuted in July 1994.

A New President Is Appointed at Barneys
description: Barneys New York, the apparel retailer, said yesterday that Charles W. Bunstine 2d, formerly its senior vice president, had been promoted to president and chief operating officer.

title: Fans Are Glad, Mad Or Just Indifferent
description: "They settled? That's good."

title: School Case Displays High Court Divisions on Desegregation
description: The Supreme Court's fault lines on the subject of desegregation remedies were starkly obvious today as the Justices heard arguments on whether the state of Missouri had met its obligation to dismantle the legacy of segregation in the Kansas City school system.

title: Suffolk Chief Calls for Cut In Lilco's Electricity Rates
description: Just three months after former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo called for a state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, the Suffolk County Executive said today that customers could save just as much money if the company were forced to cut its staff and reduce its dividends.

title: Friends, Again, At Least For Show
description: Robert Plant and Jimmy Page thought they could pull a fast one. The two estranged members of Led Zeppelin decided to reunite last year, perform new versions of old Zeppelin songs for an MTV special and embark on a world tour without inviting John Paul Jones, the bassist and keyboardist, to join them. In fact, they didn't even tell him about it; in an interview last year, Mr. Jones said he was upset when he found out about the reunion through a newspaper article.

title: Western Digital Corp.(WDC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods ended Dec. 25.Revenue represented net revenues.

title: The Neediest Cases; Contributing as a Family Tradition Ingrained Early in Life
description: Emma Kates-Shaw is not old enough to appreciate traditions, but eventually, she might grow fond of one that began in her first year of life. Last month, her parents sent $50 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to celebrate her first Christmas and start an annual routine.

title: Maurice Saatchi Is Forming A New Independent Shop
description: Eight days after Maurice Saatchi's ouster as chairman of Saatchi & Saatchi led him to quit the world's fifth-largest agency company in anger, the colorful British advertising executive is forming his own breakaway shop.

title: Grants Help Explain Urban Environment
description: Martha Cooper, a photographer, is studying vernacular architecture, including the small, free-standing houses, or casitas, that are scattered on vacant lots in places like East Harlem.

title: Prosecution Says Simpson Abused Wife For 17 Years
description: In an effort to bolster their arguments for introducing evidence of domestic violence at trial, prosecutors in the murder case against O. J. Simpson asserted in court documents released today that he had abused Nicole Brown Simpson for 17 years.

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
Tar Heels Hold Off Georgia Tech Rally
description: North Carolina continues to struggle to find its offensive rhythm. The fourth-ranked Tar Heels also continue to win, staving off a second-half rally by Georgia Tech tonight to post an 86-75 victory at the Smith Center.

title: Colombia Denies Island Is a Drug Haven
description: Colombian authorities denied today that a Caribbean island, San Andres, serves as a haven for drug traffickers and that old jets like Boeing 727's and French Caravelles are being used to transport cocaine from the island to Mexico.

title: Jack G. Thayer; Radio Executive, 72
description: Jack G. Thayer, chief operating officer and executive vice president of Gear Broadcasting International and former president of NBC radio, died on Jan. 1 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Providence, R.I. He was 72 and lived in Providence and Manhattan.

title: Utility Regulators to Study Buried-Cable Signs
description: New Jersey regulators say they will study whether a clearer system of markings is needed for the paths of buried cables and pipelines before construction crews begin working near them.

title: Movies Haven't Stolen Tim Allen's Attention
description: How does a performer follow the spectacular success of having the top-rated television show, the highest-grossing holiday movie and the No. 1 best-selling book all at the same time? If the performer is Tim Allen of ABC's "Home Improvement," he shrugs off movies and decides to do theater.

title: White House Moves to Increase Aid to Mexico
description: The Clinton Administration moved today to increase its aid package for Mexico, warning members of Congress that more money may be needed for new, subsidized loans.

title: Broken Pesos, Broken Promises
description: To anyone who follows Mexican professional wrestling, the political crisis set off by the devaluation of the peso was no surprise at all. Attendance at wrestling matches has dropped as precipitously as the currency -- a clear sign that Mexicans have stopped believing that the good guys ever win.

title: Kennedy Implores Democrats to Stick to Their Party's Values
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who turned a losing race into a landslide victory last fall by re-emphasizing his liberal values, said today that his party could rebound, "but only if we stand for something."

title: Celanese Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The per-share impact was not provided in both the quarter and year.Year-ago results are restated to reflect an accounting change.The company said that all share earnings figures reflected a 3-for-1 stock split in May 1994.Results are in Canadian dollars.Celanese Canada with a ticker symbol of CCL is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Ready to Skate but Far From Happy
description: In effect, they took one for the team.

title: Convict Says DNA Shows His Innocence In '84 Killing
description: Days after he was convicted of raping and murdering a 16-year-old Long Island girl, Dennis Halstead began making hundreds of phone calls. He called the White House, the Governor's office and virtually anyone who would listen.

title: Remarks by Clinton Halt Slide of Stocks
description: President Clinton's willingness to lend Mexico more money to overcome its economic crisis reassured investors today and buoyed the Mexican stock exchange after two days of steep losses.

title: Useful, if Tame, Labor Reforms
description: The U.S. is enjoying peaceful labor-management relations. Yet serious problems persist. Outdated laws prevent workers from joining labor-management teams to discuss ways to improve productivity and quality. Employers flout workers' right to organize unions free of retaliation. A third of all non-union workers want to join unions, but are thwarted by the majority of workers who do not.

title: F.T.C. Approves Lockheed-Martin Marietta Deal
description: In a unanimous vote, the Federal Trade Commission gave its approval yesterday to the Lockheed Corporation's merger with the Martin Marietta Corporation, eliminating the last Government obstacle to creating a $10 billion enterprise that will be the world's largest maker of military hardware.

title: Collected Pieces From a Passionate Life
description: FOR several months in 1990, while reporting an article on Rudolf Nureyev, I found myself, memo book in hand, in the daunting presence of the man who kindled my passion for dance and permanently ingrained in me a romantic ideal that would prove entirely unattainable.

title: Ancient Necessity Gets a New Look
description: THEY'RE made of brass or chrome, with a polished or satin finish. They come in two sleek shapes: an elongated diamond (right) and a stylized leaf (below). They're modern andirons, designed by Stephen Doyle and Miguel Oks, two partners in Drenttel Doyle Projects, a New York design firm. "The andirons seem to float in front of the logs they support," Mr. Doyle said. "They are designed to embody the qualities of light and fire, faceted to reflect light." They are $2,250 a pair from John Boone, a trade showroom at 1059 Third Avenue, near 63d Street, (212) 758-0012.
