title: Defying the Confines of Labels and Race
description: EMMA AMOS'S paintings have descended on the Montclair Art Museum like a flock of tropical birds -- gaudy, raucous and seemingly bent on mischief. "Changing the Subject," as this traveling show is called, has been organized by Holly Block, who directs Art in General, an alternative space in Manhattan that specializes in emerging artists of all ages and stripes.

description: They have lost their second-leading scorer to academic problems. Their star center has struggled. And today another veteran guard was sidelined.

description: Plans for a Middle East development bank, widely seen as an important vehicle to promote peace efforts in the region, are being scaled back in an attempt to overcome opposition from Saudi Arabia and some European countries, American and Middle Eastern diplomats say.

TECHNOLOGY VIEW;
Mr. Toad, Amazed, Hears the Wind From the Towers
description: WHETHER THE NEW RAGE for home theater is more accurately characterized as a groundswell or an onslaught may depend on your perspective. While some view the dawning of five-channel sound as technological progress -- or a marketing opportunity -- others see a rising threat to the serious pleasure of listening to music.

title: Layers of History in Fribourg
description: MARCHING up the hillsides of the medieval city of Fribourg just 17 miles southwest of Bern, straddling the border between French- and German-speaking Switzerland, are ancient houses in the Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque styles. Only a few years ago they were considered undesirable, but now, in the throes of gentrification, they have become sought after. Halfway up, rows of 16th- to 18th-century private residences with oaken doors and finely worked grills convey a sense of old wealth along the Grand-Rue.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the Travel Advisory page on Nov. 6 referred incorrectly to the tax on some car rentals in Spain. A reader's letter received on Dec. 23 pointed out that rentals in the Balearic and Canary Islands are not exempt from tax. The rate is 16 percent in the Balearics (it was 15 percent until Dec. 31) and 4 percent in the Canaries. This correction was delayed through an editing oversight.

title: 30 Years Later, Ball Might Be in Their Court
description: In a city where space is tight, it pays to watch out: your basketball court might be turned into a church sanctuary before you know it.

title: Small School Going One-on-One With City Children
description: A SCHOOL that seeks out the urban children hardest hit by poverty, violence, drugs, hunger and broken homes and then tries to educate them could be considered a hopelessly romantic and idealistic venture. Most public schools, with just a percentage of these children, have a hard enough time coping. Recruiting at-risk students and then nurturing them into their middle-school years might seem a thankless task.

title: Krone Is Expected Back Within a Month
description: Julie Krone underwent surgery yesterday to repair a fracture of the little finger on her left hand. But it was the only reminder of the violent four-horse spill she endured at Gulfstream Park on Friday, and she was expected to return to racing in two to four weeks.

title: The Road to Zanzibar Is Getting Busier
description: Zanzibar, once a center of the spice trade, has been attracting the tourist trade of late. Hotels and cultural sites on the island off the east coast of Africa had fallen into disrepair owing to government neglect. But in the last few years, the Government (Zanzibar and Tanganyika united in 1964 to become Tanzania) has encouraged tourism investment, and improved facilities have begun drawing travelers, many of them adding stops on Zanzibar to longer East Africa tours. One of the island's chief attractions is the Stone Town section of the city of Zanzibar, with its narrow, winding streets and balconied limestone houses with ornately carved doors. Visitors also may tour farms where clove, cinnamon, nutmeg and cardamom are grown, or swim at Indian Ocean beaches.

title: Nonviolence Institute Seeks Peaceful Change
description: THE legacy of the civil rights movement may now be the stuff of public televisiondocumentaries and history courses, but to nearly two dozen dedicated volunteers in the county, the ideals of applying strategies of nonviolence for social change espoused by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. aren't academic, but alive and well.

title: Fetisov Isn't at Front of Line
description: The chances of Slava Fetisov joining the Devils in the immediate future were somewhat reduced this evening when Lou Lamoriello, the president and general manager, said a defenseman from Albany would join the team instead.

title: Corrections
description: A picture last Sunday with a report about the wedding of Rebecca Emily Meyers and Michael David Wiederhorn was published in error. It showed Kimberly Jane Morris and Paul Jonas Silverstein, who were married on Dec. 29.

title:
FILM VIEW;
Portraying 'Little Women' Through the Ages
description: THE THREE EXTANT FILM versions of "Little Women" give audiences a view of prevailing tastes in American movie good girls. Through the medium of a beloved classic story, each one displays the current fashion in what groups of girls in movies should be like. The 1933 version had the Sweetheart and the Siren trumped by the Enthusiast, with Mother an aging character part. The 1949 version had the Girl Next Door take precedence over two types of Prom Queen, and Mother was Still Lovely. And the current version offers a range of Self-Realized Women of all ages -- today, nobody is old. We could even guess that the lost silent-film versions -- an American one in 1918 and an earlier British one -- had Madcap Hoydens balanced with Submissive Damsels, and that Mother had the correct silver hair.

title: Jan. 8-14: El Nino's Return; Unrelenting Rains Punish Much of California
description: California has long endured severe natural hazards -- earthquakes, wildfires, mudslides. This winter it is flooding, from the redwood country in the north to Malibu near Los Angeles, as a recurring Pacific weather phenomenon known as El Nino pushes the jet stream out of its normal position and steers storm after storm toward the state.

title: Finding the Bargains Amid the Peso's Decline
description: AT last count, the battered Mexican peso had lost somewhere near 40 percent of its value against the dollar in less than a month.. Although it may seem predatory to think of bargains while Mexicans are trying to recover from the economic shock of the devaluation, the misfortune of America's neighbor opens a world of possibilities for travelers -- at least for the short term -- especially those willing to explore.

title: Kotite's Role
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Problems With Goliath? Boycott the Philistines!
description: David, in the form of Boycott Quarterly, is alive and well and has a circulation of about 3,000. The magazine of indefatigable ambitions, now on its seventh issue, encourages boycotts as a form of political action and publishes a list of about 100-150 boycotts it feels are worth supporting. Among the targets are the Goliaths of China and the Disney company. Chinese-made toys made the list because of Tiananmen Square, and Disney's Dolphin Resort in Florida is under attack because of an English-only policy for its employees. Zachary D. Lyons, the editor and publisher of Boycott Quarterly, based in Seattle, insists that boycotts can succeed even in the face of enormous odds. His motto, "One Dollar/One Vote" seems like a recipe for grass roots power at first glance. But how many votes does that give Disney?

title: Protestant and Paranoid in Northern Ireland; By John Darnton
description: When the Protestant paramilitaries decided to proclaim a cease-fire late last year, they chose Gusty Spence to announce it. Spence, at 61, is a retired terrorist. He is the father figure -- if that's the right term -- of modern-day loyalist violence in Northern Ireland. In 1966 he founded the Ulster Volunteer Force, a murderous gang that took its name from a private army of unionists that sprang up just before World War I to provoke a civil war rather than break from Britain. Later that year, after he had killed a young Catholic barman, Spence was sentenced to life in Long Kesh prison. Somewhere along the way he repented, turned his back on violence and, after 18 years, was released. To the extremists he's still a revered figure.

title:
Commercial Property/The Preservation Specialty;
Landmarks Plug Construction Gap
description: CONSTRUCTION management firms and general contractors competing for work in the hardscrabble New York City building industry rarely speak with one voice, but they have reached a consensus about one aspect of business.

title: A 50's Musical Sendup in 'Forever Plaid'

title: Try Not to Stare At the Ceiling
description: LAST Wednesday night, a shoulder-to-shoulder crowd of 400 celebrated the opening of Zut!, a French bistro-style restaurant on Duane Street in TriBeCa. The focal point of the packed dining room was a pair of six-feet-wide chandeliers by Marta Baumiller, each fitted with 13 foppish hats that conceaed incandescent light bulbs and were trimmed with wide black grosgrain ribbon. The walls were covered with 1940's paper found in France, depicting little animals doing things like wearing hats and sipping martinis.

title: WHICH COUNTS MORE, GENDER OR RACE?
description: I am not sure that Bebe Moore Campbell and Joyce Carol Oates actually had a conversation, as your title suggests ("Which Counts More, Gender or Race?" Dec. 25). A conversation implies an exchange of thoughts and feelings. "An Interview of Ms. Campbell by Ms. Oates" might have been a more appropriate title. Oates assumed an intellectualized stance, from which she commented on Campbell's views with statements like "yeah," "hmmm," "right" and "interesting." These are the sorts of comments therapists often use to convey empathy. While there is nothing wrong with this, I was disappointed at Oates's reluctance to express her own thoughts. Campbell, on the other hand, spoke forthrightly. I appreciated her observations. ANN EICHEN EPSTEIN Baltimore

title: A City Asks For a Return On Its Dollar
description: MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI'S new urban agenda is a political alchemist's ingenious formula for coping with diminishing returns from Albany and Washington: He argues that New York, like many other American cities, is a well-capitalized national economic resource that would be largely self-sufficient if only the state and Federal governments got out of its way.

title: A Bad Week In the Asian Markets, Too
description: Traders in the stock and currency markets of East Asia braced for another hard week as the aftershocks of Mexico's financial crisis continued to pound emerging markets in the region.

title: Dr. King's Memorial
description: With the year 2000 now in sight, it is clear that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was the most important public figure to emerge from the Deep South in the 20th century. He was not simply a regional figure, of course. By destroying segregation in his home territory, he redefined America's approach to human rights and released political energies that have touched citizens as far away as China and South Africa.

title: Albany Begins to Open Up
description: Congress has been doing it for years. So have various states. Now, after years of neglect, the two top leaders of New York's Legislature have pledged to provide an itemized accounting of the portly, padded legislative budget. That would help ventilate the cocoon that has long surrounded lawmakers' spending, especially in the Republican Senate. It is also one of several promising new moves toward a more open and accountable legislature.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Some people may find it hard to envision MARYLOU WHITNEY, the socialite and grand dame of the Saratoga racing scene, mushing through the wilds of Alaska, but that is exactly what she has been doing lately. title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Colbert Recovers to Beat Albus in Playoff Jim Colbert made a remarkable recovery on the third hole of a playoff, then made a 3-foot putt to beat Jim Albus yesterday in the Senior Tournament of Champions in Dorado, Puerto Rico. Colbert, whose tee shot on the third extra hole found a bunker behind a tree, split two palm trees with his approach, then watched as the ball landed 5 feet beyond a green-side bunker and rolled to within 3 feet of the cup. Colbert made the winning putt after Albus's birdie attempt from 10 feet missed. Both had finished 54 holes on the 6,740-yard Hyatt Dorado Beach East course with under-par 209 totals. For Colbert, the victory completed a major reversal. He finished tied for last place in November's season-ending Senior Tour Championship. (AP)

title: Farrakhan Case Informer: A Man Living on the Edge
description: Michael Fitzpatrick, the man who the authorities say turned in the daughter of Malcolm X and accused her of trying to hire him to kill Louis Farrakhan, has emerged as the central figure in the case, shadowed by intrigue and a history of enticing others to wrongdoing.

title: In Japan, It's Chic to Eat American Apples
description: To the Editor:

title: Fehr on a Mission in Venezuela
description: DONALD FEHR, the union chief, is due to arrive in Caracas, Venezuela, today to ask local players not to break ranks with fellow major leaguers.

title: Ministers Raise Voices in Face of the Death Penalty
description: In the cavernous sanctuary of the Concord Baptist Church in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the Rev. Gary V. Simpson grasped the pulpit yesterday acknowledging that the return of the death penalty to New York seemed virtually assured. But he then went on to offer parishioners a passionate attack on capital punishment.

title: Savings Bond Sales Fall
description: Sales of series EE savings bonds declined 20.2 percent in December, to $784 million from $983 million a year earlier, the Treasury said last week. Sales have declined since the minimum guaranteed interest rate on savings bonds was lowered to 4 percent from 6 percent in 1993.

title: World News Briefs; U.S. Warns Airlines Of Threat in East Asia
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered United States airlines flying to and from East Asia to increase security measures as a result of bomb threats, a State Department official said tonight.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; From an earthquake, a cross-country move and an image makeover for Redken hair care products.
description: AN upheaval that begins this week in the competitive realm of hair care product advertising can trace its roots to, of all things, an earthquake.

title: Oren Root, 83, Banking Official And a Rockefeller Adviser, Dies
description: Oren Root, a former New York Superintendent of Banks and an aide and adviser to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, died on Saturday at his home in Bedford, N.Y. He was 83.

title: At Party's Helm, a Gritty Politician
description: William D. Powers lost his patronage job with the New York State Legislature in 1980 for supporting Alfonse M. D'Amato's successful campaign to wrest the Republican nomination from the United States Senator Jacob K. Javits but landed another post anyway: on Senator D'Amato's payroll. A decade later, rejecting Mr. D'Amato's advice but winning his blessing, Mr. Powers captured the state chairmanship of a party that was financially and politically bankrupt.

title: No Doubt About It: Heat Is Up for Sampras And Sanchez Vicario
description: It's hot and it's humid and it's the Grand Slam tournament where, appropriately enough, players learn just how it feels to be a shrimp on the barbie. According to Pete Sampras, you can't survive two weeks at the Australian Open without experiencing the sensation of being broiled alive.

title: JAZZ
description: Murray the Composer, Eloquent Across the Genres David Murray, saxophonist Knitting Factory

title: Healthy Rangers Proving Time Does Heal All Wounds
description: Colin Campbell has plenty of things to worry about as the Rangers prepare for their season opener on Friday, but team injuries is not one of them.

title: A New Chairman Is Selected For Assembly Schools Panel
description: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has named Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat, as chairman of the influential education committee, charging him with protecting New York City's schools in a year when Gov. George E. Pataki has pledged to cut state spending.

title: 49ers and Chargers Going to Super Bowl
description: The San Francisco 49ers yesterday fulfilled the promise first hinted at last summer. But the Pittsburgh Steelers ended their day stunned. In San Francisco, the 49ers soundly defeated the Dallas Cowboys, 38-28, in the National Football Conference championship game to advance to Super Bowl XXIX in two weeks in Miami. In Pittsburgh, the San Diego Chargers upset the Steelers by 17-13 in the American Football Conference championship in a game decided by a last-minute goal-line stand. The Chargers will face the 49ers in the Super Bowl. Above, San Francisco quarterback Steve Young lunged into the end zone for a 3-yard touchdown in the third quarter. At right, the Chargers' Dennis Gibson (57) knocked the ball away from Pittsburgh's Barry Foster to deny the Steelers a last-minute game-winning touchdown.

title: Now for a Politically Correct 'Star Trek'
description: equence under way. Engage!" And the "Star Trek" franchise blasts off once again. Consider merely this one statistic being bandied about by the producers: There are already more than 325 hours of "Star Trek" productions, including the original series (which began in 1966), the seven feature films and the television spinoffs, "Star Trek: The Next Generation (1987)" and "Star Trek: Deep Space Nine (1993)."

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday Industrial Production . . . . Dec. Capacity Utilization . . . Dec. Wednesday Business Inventories . . . Nov. Thursday Balance of Trade . . . Nov. Weekly Jobless Claims Friday Housing Starts . . . Dec.

title: Confusion Marks Polish Plan To Commemorate Auschwitz
description: Elie Wiesel, the Nobel laureate, expressing unease at the confusion surrounding ceremonies planned by the Polish Government to mark the 50th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, said today that he was not sure whether he would attend.

title: Barber's 'Vanessa,' Long Neglected, Is Revived
description: Like many American operas, Samuel Barber's "Vanessa" started strong and then faded. Its initial reception at the Metropolitan Opera in 1958 was wildly enthusiastic; Dimitri Mitropoulos, who conducted the first performance, exclaimed, "At last, an American grand opera!" But the Met lost interest in the work a few years later, and Cecil Beaton's sumptuous sets were destroyed in a 1973 fire. The Washington Opera's visually splendid new staging, a co-production with the Dallas Opera that opened on Saturday at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, is one of very few attempts at this score in recent decades.

title: A Feud Begins Among Simpson's Lawyers
description: As O. J. Simpson heads for trial this week on murder charges, an extraordinary and apparently irreparable breach has developed between two of his lawyers: Robert L. Shapiro and Mr. Shapiro's former mentor, F. Lee Bailey.

title: Woman Held in the Death of Her Newborn Baby
description: A Bronx woman who was allegedly working as a prostitute in her ninth month of pregnancy was arrested yesterday after her newborn baby was found dead, the police said.

title: A Painful Recovery
description: Severely injured after being shot by a robber, Frederick B. had to quit his job and faced a painful, lonely recovery. He received a small amount of worker's compensation and public assistance, but it was not enough to pay his bills. "I had never felt so helpless," he said. Then Catholic Charities stepped in.

title: First Commonwealth Financial Corp.(FCF,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 1.6 million, or 7 cents a share.c-After a gain of $ 865,000, or 4 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: CHAMPIONSHIPS: Sports of The Times; In the Final Analysis, Jones and Cowboys Die With Their Boots
description: OUTSIDE, after he accepted the National Conference trophy, Eddie DeBartolo's voice thundered through Candlestick Park's public-address system.

title: Washington Federal S & L Assn.-Seattle (WFSL,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article in the Week in Review yesterday about foreign policy and the Republicans in Congress omitted several words in a statement by the historian Michael Beschloss, altering its meaning. Mr. Beschloss said that in 1980, almost every major Republican leader agreed with "the critique of what Jimmy Carter was doing." He did not say that the Republicans agreed with President Carter's foreign policy.

title: Japan Is Likely to Meet Goal on U.S. Auto Parts
description: Japan's automobile industry is almost certain to achieve a target set three years ago to purchase $19 billion in American-made automobile parts this fiscal year, Government and industry officials said.

title: Los Angeles's Steel-Frame Buildings: Quake-Proof or Not?
description: In the year since the deadly Northridge earthquake, this disaster-hardened city has become aware of a frightening new danger: the fragility of the steel-frame buildings that at first seemed to have survived the shaking unscathed.

title: Today's TV Listings
description: Television and radio news, listings and advertising appear today on pages B6-7.

title: G.O.P. Governor Candidate Won't Appeal Maryland Race
description: Two days after a state court rejected her effort to overturn the Maryland governor's election won by Parris N. Glendening in November, Ellen R. Sauerbrey, the Republican challenger, said today that she had withdrawn her appeal of the court's decision.

title: CHAMPIONSHIPS: Sports of The Times; Alas, the Fall of an Empire That Never Was
description: STAN HUMPHRIES? Alfred Pupunu? The San Diego Chargers?

title: Bridge
description: One of the world's fastest analysts recently became an American resident. Martin Hoffman, a Holocaust survivor who went to England and acquired the skills of a bridge expert, now lives in Lauderhill, Fla. At the 1993 Fall Nationals, he held the South cards in a Senior Pairs event and was the declarer in four hearts after West overcalled in clubs.

title: Ralph Merrifield, Expert on London In the Roman Era
description: Ralph Merrifield, a British archeologist and an authority on London when it was under the Roman Empire, died last Monday in King's College Hospital in London. He was 81 and lived in London.

title: Breathing Room on the Homeless
description: Some advocates for the homeless are angry at former Gov. Mario Cuomo for one of his last acts in office: changing the requirement that the city house homeless people immediately. They accuse Mr. Cuomo of doing for Mr. Giuliani what he would not do for fellow Democrat David Dinkins, presumably as a payoff for the Mayor's support during Mr. Cuomo's campaign. All that is moot now, however. The deed is done and it need not be the disaster for the city's homeless that their advocates fear.

title: Swift Transport reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding reflected a 2-for-1 stock split completed on Nov. 15, 1994.

title: Comfortable Germans, Slow to Change (Especially if It Means More Work)
description: Life for the 16 million people in the former East Germany has been transformed since reunification in 1990, but change has come slower among the 64 million people here in the prosperous west despite warnings that their comfortable and costly welfare state must be cut back in a new era of global economic competition.

title: Japan Pushing Information Software
description: In an attempt to catch up to the United States in multimedia technology, Japan's Government and seven major electronics companies are setting up a consortium to develop software for information networks, officials said this weekend.

title: JAZZ
description: Murray the Composer, Eloquent Across the Genres David Murray, saxophonist Knitting Factory

title: Issue Behind King Memorial: Who Owns History?
description: As a battle over real estate, the conflict between the family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the National Park Service over a parcel they both want for a monument to the civil rights leader is clear-cut, prosaic and likely to be resolved through negotiations.

title: Kvaerner Gets 3 Ship Orders
description: Kvaerner A.S. said today that it had won contracts for three cruise liners worth a total of $780 million

title: INSIDE
description: Budget Measure Unknowns

title: CPC IS SEEKING FRENCH MAYONNAISE BUSINESS
description: CPC International Inc., based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., is negotiating to acquire the Lesieur mayonnaise and salad dressings business in France from Eridania Beghin-Say. The terms were not disclosed. Lesieur products, with sales of about $100 million, are sold in France. The purchase would include Eridania Beghin-Say's smaller Cremanaze dressings business and related products, which are sold in Britain. CPC, which sells Hellmann's and Best Foods mayonnaise, said it planned to consolidate the Lesieur business with its other operations in France, which consist chiefly of Knorr soup and sauce products and Alsa and Yabon desserts.

title: AT LEAST 597 ARE KILLED IN JAPANESE QUAKE; KOBE DEVASTATED AS 2,000 BUILDINGS BUCKLE
description: A powerful earthquake shook major cities in western Japan today, killing at least 597 people, starting dozens of fires and trapping hundreds of residents in the wreckage of collapsed buildings.

title: Edward Gargan, 72, Professor of History
description: Edward T. Gargan, a scholar of modern French intellectual and social history and emeritus professor of French history at the University of Wisconsin, died on Tuesday at his home in Madison. He was 72.

title: A Tale of 2 Brothers and 2 Divergent Paths
description: William M. Bulger began his 17th year as President of the Massachusetts State Senate this month, a position he has held longer than anyone in the history of the Commonwealth. Meanwhile, his big brother, James (Whitey) Bulger, a convicted bank robber and reputed mobster, went on the lam.

title: Glencullen Journal; In Irish Pubs, Sober Talk of a New Road Hazard
description: The Irish are engaged in a countrywide debate over the pleasure of drink versus the pain of driving home and being pulled over by police officers enforcing the tough new drunken driving law.

title: Heather Watts, An Unlikely Swan, In Her Final Song
description: The choreography's the thing at the New York City Ballet. George Balanchine assiduously pursued a no-star policy in the company he founded with Lincoln Kirstein in 1948. Yet that did not mean he was uninterested in dancers of star quality.

title: ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO. (ADM,N)
description: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company said yesterday that earnings jumped 50.7 percent in its fiscal second quarter as a combination of falling American farm prices and rising overseas demand for food products pushed up profit margins.

title: The 49ers Post Second Victory
description: Fox's broadcast of the Dallas-San Francisco game generated a 34.2 preliminary Nielsen overnight rating, up 9.2 percent from last year's 31.3 rating, when CBS aired the game.

title: Budget Measure Likely but Which One?
description: The odds are good that amid much hue and cry, the necessary two-thirds of the House of Representatives will vote late this month for a Constitutional amendment ordering the Federal Government to get its budget in balance.

title: The Mark: Refuge in Risky Days
description: With political and economic troubles shaking markets not only in Latin America, but also in European countries like Spain, Italy and Sweden, investors in search of safety and stability have been fleeing to the German mark.

title: American Virtuosi Cancel Rest of Season
description: The American Virtuosi, a chamber orchestra, have canceled the remainder of their engagements this season at Gould Hall. The ensemble plans to give a performance of Handel's "Acis and Galatea" in the spring, at a place and time to be announced, its director, Kenneth Hamrick, said.

title: Continental In a Reversal
description: Continental Airlines admitted today that it erred last year in changing travel rewards for its most frequent fliers, and it reinstated the previous program.

title: Goodyear Raises Tire Prices
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company raised many of its prices as much as 5 percent yesterday and analysts predicted demand for tires would continue to surge. As a result, tire stocks rallied.

title: A Drama About Hearts, Healthy and Otherwise
description: Have a stack of tissues handy if you are settling down to watch "A Heart For Olivia," a two-hour account of a couple's efforts to save the life of their newborn daughter. The program lives up to the promise of the title of the CBS series "Before Your Eyes," as the camera goes into the operating rooms and the report digs into the feelings of Sherrie and Lonnie Maize, Olivia's parents.

title: C. J. Dauphinot Jr., 81, Leader In Latin American Securities
description: Clarence J. Dauphinot Jr., an asset manager who helped develop Latin America's financial markets after World War II, died on Friday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 81. His principal residence was in Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: Mrs. Clinton Shouldn't Start Weakening; Offensive to Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Large Shifts By Shoney's Under Way
description: Shoney's Inc., facing intense competition in the family dining business, said today that it was replacing its top management and selling off peripheral restaurant operations to focus on its namesake chain.

title: Lately, a Much More Visible Fed Chief
description: When the Clinton Administration announced its latest package of assistance to Mexico on Thursday, two men emerged from the back rooms where the deal was being shaped to explain the plan to the White House press corps. One was the new Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin. The other, however, has no formal connection to the Administration: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Eddie Bauer Chain Plans Expansion Into Dress Clothes
description: Eddie Bauer, the specialty retailer known for its outdoor-oriented casual wear, will soon sell dress clothes as well.

title: Brazil Stocks Cut Losses
description: The stock market here and the Brazilian currency rebounded somewhat today from early losses as economists cast doubt on newspaper speculation that Brazil might face an economic crisis like Mexico's.

title: Central & South West Corp.(CSR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-After a charge of $ 46,000,000, or 24 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.Year-ago results were restated to reflect the change in accounting for unbilled revenues and the adoption of SFAS No. 112, Employers' Accounting for Postemployment Benefits. These changes were made in December 1993, but were effective Jan. 1, 1993.(Loss)Central & South West attributed the improved earnings in the latest quarter to the absence in 1994 of one-time charges recorded in December 1993, higher Transok Inc. unit earnings, and increased electric revenues due to customer growth.The company attributed the improvement for the year to the absence in 1994 of one-time charges recorded in December 1993, offset in part by increased earnings in 1993 due to the cumulative effect of accounting changes; increased electric revenues due to customer growth and more normal weather patterns at Central Power & Light and Southwestern Electric Power Co., and higher Transok earnings.Central & South West said higher depreciation and interest and lower earnings from mirror construction work in progress partially offset these factors.

title: Quake Hit Japanese Area That Was Not Thought Highly Vulnerable
description: In this earthquake-prone nation, the area around Kobe in western Japan has not been known as a danger zone. Indeed, some people are said to prefer to live in western Japan in part to escape earthquakes, which have occurred much more frequently recently in Tokyo, to the east, and in northern Japan.

title: St. Louis Symphony Names Hans Vonk as Next Director
description: The St. Louis Symphony, which came to be regarded as one of the best American orchestras during the 25-year directorship of Leonard Slatkin, has appointed the Dutch conductor Hans Vonk as its next music director, the orchestra announced yesterday. Mr. Vonk is to succeed Mr. Slatkin starting with the 1996-97 season, when Mr. Slatkin is to take over the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington.

title: A Manager Returns
description: PHIL NIEKRO, the former knuckleball pitcher who won more than 300 games in the major leagues, enjoyed managing the Colorado Silver Bullets, the women's professional baseball team, so much in their debut season that he's going to do it again.

title: Flu Casts Fevered Misery Across New York Region
description: Although her cubicle at the emergency room at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center was uncomfortably warm, Martha Rivera of Manhattan wrapped herself in a sweater, scarf and thick winter coat, huddling fruitlessly against a chill that came from deep within.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN HERSEY, the novelist, who wrote "Hiroshima" and "A Bell for Adano," might not have appreciated the ceremony on Sunday designating his Key West, Fla., home a literary landmark.

title: Gander Mountain Inc.(GNDR,NNM) reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 120,000, or 4 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of the adoption of FAS 109 during the first quarter.

title: Applied Extrusion Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included settlement of shareholder litigation at an after-tax cost of $ 847,000, or 12 cents a share. The settlement is subject to court approval.The results in the latest first quarter included the operations of the company's packaging films business, which was acquired in April 1994.

title: No Headline
description: "What's neat is that we didn't expect it. It's probably been there since the earth began. But our eyes have just been opened." -- DR. GERALD J. FISHMAN, an astrophysicist, discussing lightning that shoots up, not down. [ C9:1. ]

title: Democrats Seek to Curb Effect Of Bill on Federal Mandates
description: Facing the almost certain passage of a bill that would make it harder for Congress to impose new Federal requirements on state and local governments without paying the costs, Senate Democrats this week intend to offer amendments to limit the bill's reach.

title: Questions on Coach
description: The Nevada-Las Vegas interim president, KENNY GUINN, hopes to meet with Coach TIM GRGURICH today or tomorrow and discuss his medical problems and his immediate future with the team.

title: Q&A
description: Elliptical Orbits

title: Frontier Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an adjustment, which reduced net income by $ 2.4 million, or 3 cents a share, to the gain recorded in the second quarter on the sale of Minot Telephone Co. in the quarter, and the year included pretax gains of $ 10,063,000 on the sale of assets, including Minot Telephone Co. The year also included a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 7,197,000, or 10 cents a share.c-Included pretax gains of $ 3,495,000 and $ 4,449,000 in the quarter and year, respectively, both on the sale of assets. The year also included pretax software write-offs of $ 3.3 million.Frontier said that earnings per share from normal operations, excluding gains and losses from asset sales, were 39 cents a share in the latest fourth quarter, compared with 34 cents a share, in the year-ago period.The company also said revenues for its telephone operations were $ 609.7 million for the latest fiscal year, up 2.7 percent over 1993, while operating income rose 11.6 percent to $ 183.3 million for the year. For the fourth quarter, telephone operations revenues were $ 153.6 million and operating income was $ 48.3 million, increases of 0.3 percent and 8.8 percent, respectively, over the year-ago quarter.Frontier said that total revenues and sales for its telecommunication services rose 20.2 percent in 1994 to $ 375.8 million, while operating income rose 30.4 percent to $ 40 million for the year. For the latest fourth quarter, the company said telecommunications services revenues was up 7 percent to $ 95.1 million, while operating income increased 35.1 percent to $ 12 million.The company said that revenues, expenses and operating income for its telecommunication services group no longer include the results of its New York State wireless operations following the adoption of equity accounting for the company's 50 percent ownership in the upstate cellular network in the third quarter.

title: Is the Future of China in Deng's Iron Hand?; Going Back
description: To the Editor:

title: It's a State of Delirium: UConn Men Go to 13-0
description: Kirk King's picturesque slam dunk to finish the first half did not win the game for Connecticut tonight, not with 20 more minutes of basketball to play. But it certainly changed it.

title: Couple Are Struck and Killed by L.I. Train
description: A Long Island Rail Road train struck and killed a 26-year-old man and a 20-year-old woman early this morning as they crossed the railroad tracks at an intersection just east of the Farmingdale station, the police said.

title: Possible Chrysler Vehicle
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which recently scrapped plans to build a large sport-utility vehicle based on its Ram pickup truck, may now be considering a smaller model based on its Dakota pickup, Automotive News reported today.

title: Teco Energy Inc.(TE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary one-time after-tax charge of $ 15.4 million, or 13 cents a share, from corporate restructuring, in the quarter and year.c-After an accounting charge of $ 11.2 million, or 10 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of adopting FAS 109.Teco's restructuring actions, primarily at Tampa Electric, included about 240 early retirements, the elimination of other positions and other cost control initiatives. The company expects to recover the costs of the action through reduced operating expenses over the next two years.

title: San Diego Journal; An 'Underdog Town' Welcomes Home Its Underdog Chargers
description: When earthquakes strike Southern California, overloaded telephone systems routinely fall dead as tens of thousands of people try to make urgent calls.

title: Japan's Cedar Forests Are Man-Made Disaster
description: IT was a crisp, golden day in the vast forests here, near the base of Mount Fuji, but for Shigejiro Sugiyama a stroll in the country was an encounter with an impending disaster.

title: Pioneer-Standard Electronics Inc.(PIOS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 share split on Aug. 1, 1994.Sales of the company's 50 percent-owned Pioneer Technologies Group Inc. unit are not consolidated for reporting purposes. The company records 50 percent of the affiliate's net income on the equity method.The company said that its year-to-date sales gains reflect the continued expansion of its North American market share, and the contribution of Zentronics, its Canadian distribution unit acquired June 1.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League DETROIT TIGERS -- Named Skeeter Barnes player-coach at Toledo of the International League; Rick Adair pitching coach; and Lou Pinhey trainer. National League

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy Alan Greenspan is stepping into the limelight with greater frequency, pushing Congressional leaders to support the rescue plan for Mexico and volunteering solutions to the budget deficit. While previous Federal Reserve chairmen have preferred to keep their policy roles behind the scenes, Mr. Greenspan has been willing to take public stands on issues beyond the Fed's usual direct concerns. That exposure carries risk for a central bank known for its status apart from the executive branch. [ Page D1. ] The life insurance industry is trying to improve its image with a new booklet that explains the purchase of life insurance. [ D2. ]

title: Franklin Funds to Alter Fees
description: Franklin Resources Inc. plans to introduce a revised fee structure for 49 of its 111 mutual funds, in a move that some analysts predict may hurt the company's profit.

title: Bringing Cops to Public Housing
description: Nearly 1 in 12 New Yorkers -- close to 700,000 in all -- live in housing that is owned and operated by The New York City Housing Authority. New York's public housing is orderly and well maintained compared with the violent eyesores that blight cities like Chicago. Still, as poverty has deepened, New York's public housing projects have grown poorer and more vulnerable to crime and social disintegration.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, the Personal Computers column in Science Times last Tuesday, about on-line sources of information about government, misstated the Internet address for the Internet Multicasting Service of Washington. It is http://town.hall.org.

title: In Mexico's Peace Talks, a Slow if Hopeful Beginnin
description: Despite what mediators described as a productive first meeting between Mexico's new Government and peasant rebels, people familiar with the talks cautioned today that the two sides did not even begin to discuss the issues involved in a peace settlement.

title: New York City's Undying Deficit: Slash It, and It Just Grows Back
description: Although he has already slashed $2 billion from city programs, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani still faces another budget gap in the next 18 months that will be as large, if not larger.

title: Lincoln Telecommunications Co.(LTEC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 2.2 million pretax depreciation charge and after payment for preferred dividends of $ 225,000, the net applicable to common shares was $ 33,380,000.c-After a charge of $ 23,166,000, or 71 cents a share, from a change in accounting for income taxes and after payment of preferred dividends of $ 225,000, the net applicable to common shares was $ 9.8 million.Lincoln Telecommunications said that the ''strong'' year-end earnings were the result of ''continued solid performance'' in telephone operations and outstanding growth in cellular operations. The company said it experienced ''healthy increases'' in telephone volumes in 1994 with access minutes of use up 6.5 percent over 1993, while total customer access lines in service grew 3.7 percent.The company said that cellular operations managed by the company generated growth in customers and revenues. Lincoln Telephone and First Cellular Omaha combined to gain 18,682 new subscribers during 1994, an increase of 52.8 percent over 1993. Cellular revenues in these managed markets grew by $ 10 million, or 49.8 percent, in 1994, compared with 1993.

title: Some Haitians No Longer View G.I.'s as Saviors
description: When American troops first arrived here in September, the local population greeted them as liberators. But for many in this isolated town of 25,000 at the tip of Haiti's southern peninsula, the Americans have turned out to be not saviors of the Haitian people, but rather allies of the paramilitary groups that oppressed Haitians for a generation.

title: Accounts
description: * National Westminster Bank, London, to Bartle Bogle Hegarty, London, to consolidate the media portion of its account, previously divided between Bartle Bogle, which handles the creative portion, and CIA Medianetwork, London. Billings were estimated at $38 million. * Worthington Foods Inc., Columbus, Ohio, to Fahlgren, Dublin, Ohio, to handle its account, previously at Bates U.S.A., Columbus. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Most Markets Stayed Open
description: The Government securities market and most banks were closed yesterday in observance of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday. But other financial markets and the commodities markets were open. The Treasury's regular weekly auction of bills was postponed until today.

title: Mr. Gingrich's Cyber-Revolution
description: Last week, Newt Gingrich unveiled an electronic archive that will contain every bill submitted to Congress and every speech uttered in the House and Senate. The archive -- called "Thomas" (as in Jefferson) and accessible through the Internet computer network -- is, according to Mr. Gingrich, just one part of an ambitious plan to take power away from the elite and give it back to the people. The goal is a return to a Jeffersonian past with a 21st-century twist -- the agrarian community, the glue that held 18th-century America together, is to be replaced by cyberspace.

title: CHRONICLE
description: About six months ago, JOHN CARDINAL O'CONNOR said to BARRY TUCKER, a son of the tenor RICHARD TUCKER, " 'If I give you St. Patrick's, would you do a concert in the cathedral?' ", Mr. Tucker recalled yesterday. He is the president of the Richard Tucker Music Foundation, which awards prizes and study grants to young singers.

title: Making a Unified Whole With Music and Design
description: Complexions began life last year as a company that seemed dedicated to the idea of unifying dance, music and design into an inseparable whole whose parts, ideally, were created by dancers. The dance component, created by Dwight Rhoden, had an appealing, nubbly roughness and brash enthusiasm. The performers were first-rate, headed by Desmond Richardson, one of the most gifted dancers of his generation and, like Mr. Rhoden, then a member of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Complexions returned to the New York stage on Friday night in excerpts from new dances to be performed in July. The program, presented at the Clark Studio Theater in the Rose Building at Lincoln Center, was a dispiriting affair.

title: A Memo to Chargers: Watch Game 14 Film, Then Burn It
description: They bolted to a 21-0 lead. It was all clicking for the San Francisco 49ers. Steve Young was doing his thing, darting and scrambling here and there, tossing 304 yards worth of beautiful spirals to Jerry Rice and John Taylor and Brent Jones and Ricky Watters. Watters did his thing, rushing for 53 yards and scoring on a 4-yard run. And the defense won it early. Only 3 points allowed in the first half.

title: Fears Raised On Possibility Of Fare Rise
description: The uncertainty of government subsidies for mass transit in New York could force a fare increase in the near future and is jeopardizing a plan to offer discounts to riders, transit officials said yesterday. But they added that it was too soon to predict the timing and size of a fare increase.

title: AIRGAS TO DROP BID FOR CBI INDUSTRIES UNIT
description: Airgas Inc. said yesterday that it would drop its bid for the industrial gases unit of CBI Industries, saying it was no longer willing to pay what it had originally offered. Airgas, based in Radnor, Pa., also announced plans to buy back up to one million of its common shares. Last month, CBI, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., rejected an unsolicited offer from Airgas to buy CBI's gases unit, Liquid Carbonic, for $1.45 billion in cash and the assumption of debt. As an alternative, Airgas also proposed that CBI sell its construction, engineering and other businesses to CBI's shareholders. Airgas would then acquire the gases unit in exchange for stock. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, shares of Airgas rose $3.50, to $24, and shares of CBI fell 12.5 cents, to $23.

title: Iona, With Eye on Efficiency, Picks New Head
description: After more than 20 years of ambitious expansion, Iona College has chosen a new president who says the college has to look for ways to save money and operate more efficiently.

description: DERRICK COLEMAN finally showed up for a shootaround, which is all yesterday's 107-90 victory by the Knicks over the Nets really was.

title: UBS Unit Buys More Saatchi Shares
description: Shares of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company P.L.C. surged yesterday in trading in London and New York after a unit of UBS U.K. Holdings significantly increased its holdings and became the agency company's largest single shareholder.

title: Let's Not Take Risk of Putting School Meals in Private Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: More's in It for the Male Molly Than Thought, Study Finds
description: IT had looked to all the world like a sterile affair, one built on mutual convenience and exploitation. She, an Amazon molly fish, had sought copulation with a male, not to obtain his genes and mix them with her own to spawn the next generation, but simply for a quick chemical jump start. She needed his sperm to prod her eggs to split in twain and create clonal progeny, the fry all female and identical to the mother.

title: Elaine Greene, 74, Literary Agent, Dies
description: Elaine Greene, a leading literary agent in Britain, died on Jan. 10 at a hospice in London. She was 74 and lived in London.

description: National City's improvement in per-share earnings for the 1994 fourth quarter and year was a result from higher net interest income from loan growth.

description: Moscow crime spoiled the recent World Chess Olympiad for many players and teams. Joel Benjamin of Manhattan, Board 3 of the United States squad, said, "It was so rampant that we quickly learned never to go out of the Hotel Cosmos."

title: BellSouth Pact With Sybase
description: Revoking an agreement with the Oracle Systems Corporation, the BellSouth Corporation said today that it would turn to Sybase Inc. for interactive television software.

description: b-Included charge of $ 61 million, or 9 cents a share, for work-force reduction programs at its Georgia Power Co., Mississippi Power Co. and Southern Co. Services units.Both years' share earnings and shares outstanding reflected a 2-for-1 stock split, which occurred Feb. 7, 1994.Southern Co. said that the results for its latest fourth quarter and year were hurt by mild weather throughout the year, particularly during the summer.The company said, ''Also, during 1994, we continued to make significant investments in subsidiaries related to our core business. These long-term investments, which affected our 1994 return on equity and earnings and likely will continue to have some impact in the short term, should provide solid, sustainable earnings growth in the future.''

title: Studies Point to Flaws In Lineups of Suspects
description: IT was just turning dark one October night when a young woman hitchhiker was picked up on Pacific Highway South 10 miles outside of Seattle by a man with a beard and a three-piece suit. Instead of driving her to Tacoma, the man turned into an isolated dirt road, raped her and left her by the side of the road.

title: New Class of Lightning Found High Above Clouds
description: SCIENTISTS have been studying lightning ever since Benjamin Franklin demonstrated its electrical nature some two centuries ago, and have generally felt that its nuances were understood. The bolts were white hot, hitting temperatures of 50,000 degrees Fahrenheit and strengths of several hundred million volts. Though dazzling to the eye, lightning as a scientific topic had become rather passe.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; To keep potential customers from nodding off, a paint company strives to be warm and fuzzy.
description: IF there's anything more dull than watching paint dry, it may well be watching paint advertising. Desiccated discussions of paint's durability and longevity are virtually guaranteed to cover consumers with at least a couple of coats of miasma and boredom.

title: G.O.P. Plan For Welfare Is Criticized
description: The Clinton Administration today denounced a major element of the House Republicans' welfare bill, which would replace most Federal food and nutrition programs with cash grants to be administered by the states.

title: Japan's Second-Largest Port Is Site of Heaviest Earthquake Damage
description: The earthquake that struck Japan early this morning caused major damage to one of Japan's most distinctive big cities and the country's second largest port. Thus the disaster could have a major impact on Japan's economy, at least in the short term.

title: Rebuffed by Alvarez, Miami Talks to Lubick
description: Wisconsin Coach BARRY ALVAREZ turned down a chance to be interviewed by the University of Miami for its coaching post, and Colorado State's SONNY LUBICK remained a front-runner for the job yesterday.

title: From Chinese Traditions, Up-to-the-Minute Clothes
description: Fashion, like every other aspect of American culture, is constantly absorbing the flavors of ethnic groups. In the 1970's, black designers like Stephen Burrows, Jon Haggins and Willi Smith made a splash with their use of bright colors and innovative cuts. In recent years, Asian, Latino and Indian designers have added their particular esthetics to the fashion blend.

title: Police Investigating Slain Doctor's Son
description: Since Dr. Teresita Valera Costello's body was found, the police have said they do not have a suspect in the killing. But they add that they are looking into the background of her older son, James Costello, 25.

title: EASTMAN CHEMICAL TO SELL PRODUCT LINE TO A. SCHULMAN
description: The Eastman Chemical Company said yesterday that it planned to sell its compounded polypropylene product line to A. Schulman Inc., a plastics and resins supplier in Akron, Ohio. The terms were not disclosed. The sale of the product line, which is marketed to the automotive industry, is expected to close in early 1995 and would mark Eastman's exit from the polypropylene business. Eastman, a plastics and chemicals company based in Kingsport, Tenn., said the sale should not have a material effect on its 1995 earnings. Shares of Eastman rose 87.5 cents, to $52.75, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

New in '95: Coach Ross Getting the Instruction

Mr. Gingrich recently pledged that his political action committee, Gopac, would disclose future donors. But past Gopac donors who aided the Speaker on his climb to power remain anonymous.

Now the project is finished. The installation, from a CD-ROM, went smoothly. The machine seems faster, and Wordperfect 3.0 has definitely speeded up.

description: President Clinton took a couple of hundred aides, advance men and bodyguards to a community college in western Illinois last week to press his proposals for educational tax breaks for the middle class. But he had to compete for headlines and television time with the House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, who simply answered a question on Capitol Hill.

description: In what is likely to be her last annual "State of the Dream" speech, Coretta Scott King, the widow of the slain civil rights leader, scanned the international horizon today and said she saw reasons for hope as well as reasons to redouble the efforts to build the "beloved community of Martin Luther King Jr.'s dream."

description: The General Signal Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its Leeds & Northrup subsidiary as part of its consolidation efforts. General Signal said no deals were pending and it had hired Merrill Lynch & Company as the financial adviser for the sale of the business, which makes electronic measuring and control systems for industry. The Leeds & Northrup unit had sales of about $175 million in 1994. Nino J. Fernandez, vice president of General Signal, said he expected Leeds & Northrup to sell for $140 million to $180 million. Mr. Fernandez said the sale should be completed by the second quarter of this year. General Signal, based in Stamford, Conn., makes process controls, electrical controls and other industrial technology.

title: Go After Corporate Welfare
description: Republicans will have to cut over $1 trillion out of the Federal budget over seven years in order to pay for their promise to cut taxes and balance the budget. If Social Security and defense are exempted, as many Republican leaders insist, that means the remaining programs must be cut by 30 to 40 percent. This benighted pledge, if fulfilled, will wreck Government programs, good and bad.

description: Russian bombers and helicopters swung low over the capital of the secessionist region of Chechnya today, and artillery pounded deeper south toward Chechen-held territory. The besieged Chechen rebels, who say they have forced the Russians to retreat from some buildings in the city, appeared tired and dangerously edgy.

title: MCFARLAND SAYS CHEVRON WILL SETTLE CASE
description: McFarland Energy Inc. said yesterday that the Chevron Corporation had agreed to pay $25.7 million to settle a lawsuit over a joint oil venture. McFarland had won a jury verdict ordering Chevron to pay $47.3 million in the case, but Chevron had said it would appeal. The suit came after Chevron, based in San Francisco, sold its interest in a joint venture with Seabord Oil and Gas, McFarland's predecessor company, to Stocker Resources. McFarland contended that Chevron ignored a contractual obligation to give Seabord a chance to match Stocker's offer. McFarland, based in Santa Fe Springs, Calif., said it would get about $16 million from the settlement, after fees.

description: The chief executive of Pet Products Inc., David Greenberg, bought more than 138,000 of the company's shares several days before the Hartz Mountain Corporation began a $4.25-a-share takeover bid for Pet Products.

title: Johnson Controls Inc.(JCI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Johnson Controls said that it is ''on target'' with its cost reduction program, and expects improved profitability comparisons in the second quarter of 1995, compared with the year-ago second quarter.The company had first-quarter record results and it believes that even stronger earnings comparisons will be achieved as the company goes forward through the year. Assuming no major changes in the markets in which it primarily operates, the company expects 1995 to be another excellent year.

title: DNA Sleuths Follow Disease's Tracks to 2 Very Different Genes
description: WHENEVER a lot of very good scientists spend years searching single-mindedly for a high-profile disease gene, they invariably begin fishing out all sorts of candidate genes that look, smell and wiggle like the real thing, but then prove to be frustrating red herrings. In the course of seeking the genes that contribute to hereditary colon cancer and breast cancer, for example, researchers published reports of discoveries that in short order were shown to be the wrong genes.

description: U.S. Robotics Inc. and Cisco Systems Inc. said yesterday that they would develop and market computer network equipment. U.S. Robotics, a maker of modems based in Skokie, Ill., will develop devices with Cisco's technology to make it easier for separate networks to exchange data. Under the three-year deal, U.S. Robotics will make equipment for Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif. The two companies will also market each other's products. The companies said the devices they would make would replace a host of electronics, modems and routers with one device. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of U.S. Robotics rose $3, to $50, and shares of Cisco gained 75 cents, to $36.625.

description: Frito-Lay Inc. said yesterday that it would consolidate media planning for all brands at a special media-only unit of DDB Needham Worldwide in Dallas called Team Frito-Lay. Though billings were not disclosed, trade publications estimated them at $70 million to $80 million.

description: The players' joyful faces and the noise from all around transformed a basketball game into a milepost. And nobody wanted to leave.

title: ST. JUDE MEDICAL TO TAKE FOURTH-QUARTER CHARGE
description: St. Jude Medical Inc. said yesterday that it planned to take a fourth-quarter charge of $25.3 million, or 54 cents a share, for research and development costs at a pacemaker unit that it bought last year from Siemens A.G. The charge stems from an accounting rule requiring the company to take a charge for any research and development the new unit is conducting that St. Jude does not expect to use in the future. St. Jude, the world's largest maker of heart valves, bought the unit, Pacesetter, based in Sylmar, Calif., for about $500 million in June. St. Jude, which is based in St. Paul, announced the charge after the stock market had closed. Shares of St. Jude fell $1.50, to $36.50, yesterday in Nasdaq trading.

description: The James River Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss would be worse than expected. James River, a paper company based in Richmond, said it expected a loss of about 21 cents a share for the quarter, compared with a forecast of 8 cents by 10 analysts polled by Zacks Investment Research. James River attributed the wider loss to higher costs for raw materials, including plastic resins, recycled paper and chemicals. Shares of James River fell 37.5 cents, to $21.25, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

Mr. Grasso's Death Wish
description: Delivering on a campaign pledge, Gov. George Pataki has shipped the confessed multiple murderer Thomas Grasso from New York to Oklahoma, where the prisoner has waived all defenses to a quick execution. The pledge, which was cheap politically, and its fulfillment, billed as a cost savings for New York's prisons, are meant to look "tough" on criminals. Actually they amount to a rare state capitulation to a killer's desire to choose his own punishment.

description: The stock of the Charles Schwab Corporation, which has risen 33 percent since mid-December, climbed to a record high yesterday. In "The Underground Guide to Word for Windows," the author, Woody Leonhard, writes, "If you think it's easy, you haven't been trying." Salem, a maker of heavy equipment based in Pittsburgh, said the price was too low, but it would still consider an offer from Harbour. Harbour Group, an equity fund based in St. Louis, has made two previous offers, the most recent for $17.50 a share, or about $33.3 million.
